   796â†’        posts = extract_posts_from_draft(detail)
   797â†’        if not posts:
   798â†’            print(f"  Skipping {draft_id}: no X posts found")
   799â†’            continue
   800â†’
   801â†’        thread_info = {
   802â†’            "id": draft_id,
   803â†’            "title": draft.get("draft_title"),
   804â†’            "published_at": draft.get("published_at", ""),
   805â†’            "x_url": draft.get("x_published_url", ""),
   806â†’            "posts": posts,
   807â†’        }
   808â†’
   809â†’        # Detect day number from first post
   810â†’        day_num = detect_day_from_posts(posts)
   811â†’        thread_info["day"] = day_num
   812â†’
   813â†’        threads_data.append(thread_info)
   814â†’
   815â†’        media_count = sum(len(p.get("media_ids", [])) for p in posts)
   816â†’        day_label = f"Day {day_num}" if day_num else f"#{draft_id}"
   817â†’        print(f"  {day_label}: {len(posts)} posts, {media_count} media (published {thread_info['published_at'][:10]})")
   818â†’
   819â†’    # Download media and write per-thread files
   820â†’    print()
   821â†’    for t in threads_data:
   822â†’        if t["day"]:
   823â†’            thread_dir = SCRIPT_DIR / "threads" / f"day{t['day']}"
   824â†’        else:
   825â†’            thread_dir = SCRIPT_DIR / "threads"
   826â†’        thread_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
   827â†’
   828â†’        # Download media for this thread
   829â†’        has_media = any(p.get("media_ids") for p in t["posts"])
   830â†’        if has_media:
   831â†’            day_label = f"Day {t['day']}" if t['day'] else f"#{t['id']}"
   832â†’            print(f"  Downloading media for {day_label}...")
   833â†’            t["posts"] = download_thread_media(t["posts"], thread_dir, headers, social_set_id)
   834â†’
   835â†’        per_thread_md = format_per_thread(t)
   836â†’        if t["day"]:
   837â†’            out_path = thread_dir / "published.md"
   838â†’        else:
   839â†’            out_path = thread_dir / f"published_{t['id']}.md"
   840â†’
   841â†’        out_path.write_text(per_thread_md)
   842â†’        print(f"  Wrote {out_path.relative_to(SCRIPT_DIR)}")
   843â†’
   844â†’    # Write combined file
   845â†’    combined_md = format_combined(threads_data)
   846â†’    PUBLISHED_THREADS_PATH.write_text(combined_md)
   847â†’    print(f"\n  Combined: {PUBLISHED_THREADS_PATH.relative_to(SCRIPT_DIR)}")
   848â†’    print(f"\nDone. {len(threads_data)} threads saved.")
   849â†’
   850â†’
   851â†’def extract_posts_from_draft(detail):
   852â†’    """Extract post texts and media IDs from a Typefully draft detail response.
   853â†’
   854â†’    Returns list of dicts: [{"text": str, "media_ids": list[str]}, ...]
   855â†’    """
   856â†’    platforms = detail.get("platforms", {})
   857â†’    x = platforms.get("x", {})
   858â†’    posts_raw = x.get("posts", [])
   859â†’    result = []
   860â†’    for p in posts_raw:
   861â†’        if p.get("text"):
   862â†’            result.append({
   863â†’                "text": p["text"],
   864â†’                "media_ids": p.get("media_ids", []) or [],
   865â†’            })
   866â†’    return result
   867â†’
   868â†’
   869â†’def fetch_media_urls(media_id, headers, social_set_id):
   870â†’    """Resolve a Typefully media_id to CDN URLs. Returns dict with small/medium/large/original."""
   871â†’    try:
   872â†’        import requests
   873â†’    except ImportError:
   874â†’        return {}
   875â†’    url = f"https://api.typefully.com/v2/social-sets/{social_set_id}/media/{media_id}"
   876â†’    r = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
   877â†’    if not r.ok:
   878â†’        return {}
   879â†’    data = r.json()
   880â†’    return data.get("media_urls", {})
   881â†’
   882â†’
   883â†’def download_media(url, dest_path):
   884â†’    """Download a file from URL to dest_path. Returns True on success."""
   885â†’    try:
   886â†’        urllib.request.urlretrieve(url, str(dest_path))
   887â†’        return True
   888â†’    except Exception as e:
   889â†’        print(f"    Warning: failed to download {url}: {e}")
   890â†’        return False
   891â†’
   892â†’
   893â†’def download_thread_media(posts, thread_dir, headers, social_set_id):
   894â†’    """Download all media for a thread's posts. Returns posts with local media paths added.
   895â†’
   896â†’    Each post dict gets a 'media_paths' key with list of relative paths (relative to thread_dir).
   897â†’    """
   898â†’    media_dir = thread_dir / "media"
   899â†’    media_created = False
   900â†’
   901â†’    for post_idx, post in enumerate(posts):
   902â†’        post["media_paths"] = []
   903â†’        for mid in post.get("media_ids", []):
   904â†’            urls = fetch_media_urls(mid, headers, social_set_id)
   905â†’            if not urls:
   906â†’                continue
   907â†’
   908â†’            # Prefer original, fallback to large
   909â†’            dl_url = urls.get("original") or urls.get("large")
   910â†’            if not dl_url:
   911â†’                continue
   912â†’
   913â†’            # Derive extension from URL
   914â†’            ext = ".jpg"
   915â†’            url_path = dl_url.split("?")[0]
   916â†’            if "." in url_path.split("/")[-1]:
   917â†’                ext = "." + url_path.split("/")[-1].rsplit(".", 1)[1]
   918â†’
   919â†’            filename = f"post{post_idx + 1}_{mid[:8]}{ext}"
   920â†’            dest = media_dir / filename
   921â†’
   922â†’            if not media_created:
   923â†’                media_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
   924â†’                media_created = True
   925â†’
   926â†’            if dest.exists():
   927â†’                post["media_paths"].append(f"media/{filename}")
   928â†’                continue
   929â†’
   930â†’            if download_media(dl_url, dest):
   931â†’                post["media_paths"].append(f"media/{filename}")
   932â†’                print(f"    Downloaded {filename}")
   933â†’
   934â†’    return posts
   935â†’
   936â†’
   937â†’def detect_day_from_posts(posts):
   938â†’    """Try to detect [DAY N] from the first post."""
   939â†’    if posts:
   940â†’        text = posts[0]["text"] if isinstance(posts[0], dict) else posts[0]
   941â†’        m = re.search(r"\[DAY\s+(\d+)\]", text, re.IGNORECASE)
   942â†’        if m:
   943â†’            return int(m.group(1))
   944â†’    return None
   945â†’
   946â†’
   947â†’def format_per_thread(thread_info):
   948â†’    """Format a single thread as LLM-ready markdown."""
   949â†’    day = thread_info["day"]
   950â†’    pub_date = thread_info["published_at"][:10] if thread_info["published_at"] else "unknown"
   951â†’    posts = thread_info["posts"]
   952â†’    total = len(posts)
   953â†’
   954â†’    lines = []
   955â†’    if day:
   956â†’        lines.append(f"# Day {day} â€” Published {pub_date}")
   957â†’    else:
   958â†’        lines.append(f"# Thread â€” Published {pub_date}")
   959â†’
   960â†’    if thread_info["x_url"]:
   961â†’        lines.append(f"url: {thread_info['x_url']}")
   962â†’
   963â†’    lines.append("")
   964â†’
   965â†’    for i, post in enumerate(posts, 1):
   966â†’        text = post["text"] if isinstance(post, dict) else post
   967â†’        lines.append(f"{i}/{total}")
   968â†’        lines.append(text.strip())
   969â†’        # Add media references
   970â†’        if isinstance(post, dict):
   971â†’            for path in post.get("media_paths", []):
   972â†’                lines.append(f"![]({path})")
   973â†’        lines.append("")
   974â†’
   975â†’    return "\n".join(lines)
   976â†’
   977â†’
   978â†’def format_combined(threads_data):
   979â†’    """Format all threads into a single LLM-ready context file."""
   980â†’    lines = ["# Published Threads", ""]
   981â†’
   982â†’    for t in threads_data:
   983â†’        day = t["day"]
   984â†’        pub_date = t["published_at"][:10] if t["published_at"] else "unknown"
   985â†’        posts = t["posts"]
   986â†’        total = len(posts)
   987â†’
   988â†’        if day:
   989â†’            lines.append(f"## Day {day} â€” Published {pub_date}")
   990â†’        else:
   991â†’            lines.append(f"## Thread â€” Published {pub_date}")
   992â†’
   993â†’        if t["x_url"]:
   994â†’            lines.append(f"url: {t['x_url']}")
   995â†’
   996â†’        lines.append("")
   997â†’
   998â†’        for i, post in enumerate(posts, 1):
   999â†’            text = post["text"] if isinstance(post, dict) else post
  1000â†’            lines.append(f"{i}/{total}")
  1001â†’            lines.append(text.strip())
  1002â†’            if isinstance(post, dict):
  1003â†’                for path in post.get("media_paths", []):
  1004â†’                    # In combined file, use path relative to threads dir
  1005â†’                    day_prefix = f"threads/day{day}/" if day else "threads/"
  1006â†’                    lines.append(f"![]({day_prefix}{path})")
  1007â†’            lines.append("")
  1008â†’
  1009â†’        lines.append("---")
  1010â†’        lines.append("")
  1011â†’
  1012â†’    return "\n".join(lines)
  1013â†’
  1014â†’
  1015â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1016â†’# gold command
  1017â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1018â†’
  1019â†’def cmd_gold(args):
  1020â†’    """Add a gold moment to gold_moments.md."""
  1021â†’    moment = args.moment
  1022â†’    day = args.day
  1023â†’
  1024â†’    # If no day specified, try to detect from thread_context.md
  1025â†’    if day is None:
  1026â†’        day = detect_current_day()
  1027â†’
  1028â†’    timestamp = datetime.datetime.now().strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M")
  1029â†’
  1030â†’    # Read existing content
  1031â†’    if GOLD_MOMENTS_PATH.exists():
  1032â†’        content = GOLD_MOMENTS_PATH.read_text()
  1033â†’    else:
  1034â†’        content = "# Gold Moments\n"
  1035â†’
  1036â†’    # Append the moment
  1037â†’    entry = f"\n- [{timestamp}] {moment}\n"
  1038â†’
  1039â†’    if day is not None:
  1040â†’        # Try to find existing Day N section
  1041â†’        day_header = f"## Day {day}"
  1042â†’        if day_header in content:
  1043â†’            # Append under existing section â€” find the next ## or end of file
  1044â†’            idx = content.index(day_header)
  1045â†’            # Find the end of this section
  1046â†’            next_section = content.find("\n## ", idx + len(day_header))
  1047â†’            if next_section == -1:
  1048â†’                content = content.rstrip() + entry
  1049â†’            else:
  1050â†’                content = content[:next_section].rstrip() + entry + "\n" + content[next_section:]
  1051â†’        else:
  1052â†’            # Create new day section
  1053â†’            content = content.rstrip() + f"\n\n{day_header}\n" + entry
  1054â†’    else:
  1055â†’        # No day â€” append at end
  1056â†’        content = content.rstrip() + "\n\n### Uncategorized\n" + entry
  1057â†’
  1058â†’    GOLD_MOMENTS_PATH.write_text(content)
  1059â†’    day_str = f" (Day {day})" if day is not None else ""
  1060â†’    print(f"Added gold moment{day_str}: {moment}")
  1061â†’
  1062â†’
  1063â†’def detect_current_day():
  1064â†’    """Try to detect the current day number from thread_context.md."""
  1065â†’    if THREAD_CONTEXT_PATH.exists():
  1066â†’        content = THREAD_CONTEXT_PATH.read_text()
  1067â†’        # Find the highest Day N reference
  1068â†’        days = re.findall(r"Day (\d+)", content)
  1069â†’        if days:
  1070â†’            return max(int(d) for d in days)
  1071â†’    return None
  1072â†’
  1073â†’
  1074â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1075â†’# CLI
  1076â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1077â†’
  1078â†’def main():
  1079â†’    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(
  1080â†’        description="Build-in-public thread CLI",
  1081â†’        formatter_class=argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter,
  1082â†’    )
  1083â†’    subparsers = parser.add_subparsers(dest="command", help="Available commands")
  1084â†’
  1085â†’    # context
  1086â†’    p_context = subparsers.add_parser("context", help="Gather context for a new thread")
  1087â†’    p_context.add_argument("--since", required=True, help="Start date (YYYY-MM-DD)")
  1088â†’    p_context.add_argument("--until", help="End date (YYYY-MM-DD, default: since + 2 days)")
  1089â†’
  1090â†’    # sessions
  1091â†’    p_sessions = subparsers.add_parser("sessions", help="Browse Claude Code sessions")
  1092â†’    p_sessions.add_argument("--since", help="Start date for listing")
  1093â†’    p_sessions.add_argument("--until", help="End date for listing")
  1094â†’    p_sessions.add_argument("--id", help="Session UUID prefix to read")
  1095â†’    p_sessions.add_argument("--output", "-o", help="Write conversation to file instead of stdout")
  1096â†’
  1097â†’    # push
  1098â†’    p_push = subparsers.add_parser("push", help="Push thread to Typefully")
  1099â†’    p_push.add_argument("file", help="Thread markdown file")
  1100â†’    p_push.add_argument("--update", help="Draft ID to update (auto-detected from state file)")
  1101â†’    p_push.add_argument("--dry-run", action="store_true", help="Show what would be pushed without sending")
  1102â†’
  1103â†’    # list
  1104â†’    subparsers.add_parser("list", help="List Typefully drafts")
  1105â†’
  1106â†’    # fetch
  1107â†’    subparsers.add_parser("fetch", help="Fetch published threads from Typefully")
  1108â†’
  1109â†’    # gold
  1110â†’    p_gold = subparsers.add_parser("gold", help="Add a gold moment")
  1111â†’    p_gold.add_argument("moment", help="Description of the gold moment")
  1112â†’    p_gold.add_argument("--day", type=int, help="Day number (auto-detected if omitted)")
  1113â†’
  1114â†’    args = parser.parse_args()
  1115â†’
  1116â†’    if not args.command:
  1117â†’        parser.print_help()
  1118â†’        sys.exit(1)
  1119â†’
  1120â†’    commands = {
  1121â†’        "context": cmd_context,
  1122â†’        "sessions": cmd_sessions,
  1123â†’        "push": cmd_push,
  1124â†’        "list": cmd_list,
  1125â†’        "fetch": cmd_fetch,
  1126â†’        "gold": cmd_gold,
  1127â†’    }
  1128â†’
  1129â†’    commands[args.command](args)
  1130â†’
  1131â†’
  1132â†’if __name__ == "__main__":
  1133â†’    main()
  1134â†’

content.content:
1â†’# Build-in-Public Thread System
     2â†’
     3â†’Portable toolkit for writing, managing, and publishing Twitter threads from development work.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Setup
     6â†’
     7â†’```bash
     8â†’# Typefully API (for pushing drafts)
     9â†’cp .env.example .env
    10â†’# Edit .env with your API key and social set ID
    11â†’
    12â†’# Slack MCP (for pulling Slack context into Claude)
    13â†’npx @jtalk22/slack-mcp --setup
    14â†’```
    15â†’
    16â†’## CLI
    17â†’
    18â†’```bash
    19â†’python3 scripts/thread/thread.py <command>
    20â†’```
    21â†’
    22â†’| Command | Description |
    23â†’|---------|-------------|
    24â†’| `context --since DATE [--until DATE]` | Gather git log, Claude sessions, gold moments |
    25â†’| `sessions --since DATE` | List Claude Code sessions by size |
    26â†’| `sessions --id UUID_PREFIX` | Read a specific session as conversation |
    27â†’| `push threads/dayN/thread.md` | Push thread to Typefully (auto-tracks draft ID) |
    28â†’| `push ... --dry-run` | Preview without sending |
    29â†’| `list` | List Typefully drafts |
    30â†’| `fetch` | Fetch published threads + media from Typefully |
    31â†’| `gold "moment" [--day N]` | Capture a gold moment with timestamp |
    32â†’
    33â†’## Structure
    34â†’
    35â†’```
    36â†’scripts/thread/
    37â†’â”œâ”€â”€ context.md         # Global: voice, rules, audiences, narratives, summaries
    38â†’â”œâ”€â”€ gold_moments.md    # Running log of compelling moments
    39â†’â”œâ”€â”€ research/          # Technical writeups, Slack messages, notes
    40â†’â”œâ”€â”€ threads/dayN/      # Per-thread folders
    41â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ published.md   #   Fetched published thread (from Typefully)
    42â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ media/         #   Downloaded images/videos from posts
    43â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ thread.md      #   Draft thread for pushing
    44â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ notes.md       #   Brainstorming, context, drafts
    45â†’â”œâ”€â”€ published_threads.md # Combined all-threads context file (generated)
    46â†’â”œâ”€â”€ images/            # Screenshots and diagrams
    47â†’â”œâ”€â”€ visuals/           # Python scripts for generating charts
    48â†’â””â”€â”€ thread.py          # This CLI
    49â†’```
    50â†’
    51â†’## Fetching published threads
    52â†’
    53â†’```bash
    54â†’python3 scripts/thread/thread.py fetch
    55â†’```
    56â†’
    57â†’Downloads all published threads from Typefully, including media (images/videos). Outputs:
    58â†’- `threads/dayN/published.md` â€” per-thread markdown with inline `![](media/...)` references
    59â†’- `threads/dayN/media/` â€” downloaded images and videos
    60â†’- `published_threads.md` â€” combined LLM-ready context file with all threads
    61â†’
    62â†’Re-running `fetch` skips already-downloaded media files.
    63â†’
    64â†’## Context sources
    65â†’
    66â†’- **Git history** â€” commits, file changes, key numbers
    67â†’- **Claude Code sessions** â€” JSONL logs at `~/.claude/projects/`
    68â†’- **Slack MCP** â€” live search/read from Slack workspace
    69â†’- **Gold moments** â€” manually captured highlights during dev
    70â†’- **Research notes** â€” technical writeups in `research/`
    71â†’
    72â†’## Portability
    73â†’
    74â†’To use in another repo:
    75â†’1. Copy `scripts/thread/`
    76â†’2. Copy `.claude/skills/build-in-public/`
    77â†’3. Create `.env` with Typefully credentials
    78â†’4. Edit `context.md` for the new project's voice and narratives
    79â†’

content.content:
1â†’# Thread Context â€” Quantum Wallet Build-in-Public
     2â†’
     3â†’## System
     4â†’
     5â†’Portable build-in-public toolkit at `scripts/thread/`.
     6â†’
     7â†’**CLI:** `python3 scripts/thread/thread.py <command>`
     8â†’- `context --since DATE` â€” gather git + sessions + gold moments
     9â†’- `sessions --since DATE` / `sessions --id UUID` â€” browse Claude sessions
    10â†’- `push threads/dayN/thread.md` â€” push to Typefully
    11â†’- `list` â€” list Typefully drafts
    12â†’- `gold "moment" --day N` â€” capture a gold moment
    13â†’
    14â†’**Context sources:**
    15â†’- `context.md` â€” this file (global: voice, narratives, summaries)
    16â†’- `gold_moments.md` â€” running log of compelling moments
    17â†’- `research/` â€” technical writeups, Slack messages, notes
    18â†’- `threads/dayN/` â€” per-thread drafts and notes
    19â†’- `images/` â€” screenshots and diagrams
    20â†’- `visuals/` â€” Python scripts for generating charts
    21â†’- **Slack MCP** â€” live access to Slack messages (search, threads, channels)
    22â†’
    23â†’## What This Is
    24â†’
    25â†’A build-in-public Twitter thread series documenting a post-quantum wallet on Starknet using Falcon-512 signatures. Each update is labeled `[DAY X]` â€” "day" means "episode," not calendar day. Posts can be days or weeks apart. Don't explain gaps.
    26â†’
    27â†’## Voice
    28â†’
    29â†’Write like I'm talking to a friend who codes.
    30â†’
    31â†’- **Casual technical.** Short sentences mixed with longer ones. Sentence fragments only when genuinely emphatic.
    32â†’- **Grammar imperfections are intentional.** Don't correct them.
    33â†’- **Confidence without performance.** "I just know it's too much" not "I believe this might be suboptimal."
    34â†’- **Show work, don't narrate it.** Code blocks and numbers over commentary.
    35â†’- **Low-key endings.** "Let's see" not "LET'S GOOO." Direction, not hype.
    36â†’- **Never use:** "Plot twist:", "ðŸ§µ", "Thread:", "Here's the thing...", "Follow for more!", "I'm excited to announce", "Unpopular opinion:". These are death.
    37â†’
    38â†’## Writing Rules (Strunk)
    39â†’
    40â†’Apply *The Elements of Style* throughout. The most common mistakes to avoid:
    41â†’
    42â†’1. **Write actual sentences.** Every sentence needs a subject and a verb. Don't stack fragments disguised as prose. Fragments are permitted only for genuine emphasis (Rule 6).
    43â†’2. **No comma splices.** Don't join independent clauses with just a comma. Use a semicolon or a conjunction (Rule 5).
    44â†’3. **Active voice.** "The compiler tracks bounds" not "bounds are tracked by the compiler" (Rule 10).
    45â†’4. **Positive form.** "The compiler skips overflow checks" not "The compiler doesn't need to add overflow checks" (Rule 11).
    46â†’5. **Specific and concrete.** "10,000-line file" not "a very large file." "122 bits" not "much smaller" (Rule 12).
    47â†’6. **Omit needless words.** Every word must tell. Cut filler (Rule 13).
    48â†’7. **Emphatic words at the end.** "This is where most of the 4x comes from" â€” the payoff lands last (Rule 18).
    49â†’8. **Tell stories, don't list facts.** "I was about to implement it, then looked at how Miden does their Falcon" â€” show the discovery journey, not a Wikipedia summary.
    50â†’
    51â†’## Audiences
    52â†’
    53â†’Write for all three simultaneously:
    54â†’
    55â†’1. **Cairo/Starknet builders** â€” core audience, full technical depth OK.
    56â†’2. **Crypto speculators/fans** â€” want stakes and progress, need anchors for unfamiliar metrics.
    57â†’3. **Ethereum/quantum researchers** â€” know PQ crypto, don't know Cairo, need technical credibility.
    58â†’
    59â†’When introducing a Cairo-specific concept, add one line of context max. Experts skip it, outsiders get a handle.
    60â†’
    61â†’## Thread Structure
    62â†’
    63â†’1. **Hook** â€” create tension. Tease a result, a contrast, or something unexpected.
    64â†’2. **Work** â€” what I actually did, with code/screenshots/numbers.
    65â†’3. **Obstacle or insight** â€” pain points are content.
    66â†’4. **Results** â€” concrete numbers, anchored to something familiar.
    67â†’5. **Closer** â€” tease what's coming next with specific stakes. Not a summary.
    68â†’
    69â†’One idea per post. Don't repeat ideas across posts â€” if the hook says it, the body doesn't say it again.
    70â†’
    71â†’## Format
    72â†’
    73â†’- Each thread quotes the previous one. Post 1 quotes the previous Day's tweet.
    74â†’- Hook starts with `[DAY X] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet.`
    75â†’- The closer should tease something specific with real stakes â€” "If X happens, then Y." End with "Let's see."
    76â†’- The last two posts (closer + second-to-last) are the most read after the hook. Make them count.
    77â†’
    78â†’## Running Narratives
    79â†’
    80â†’### Performance target
    81â†’Day 1 established ~230k Cairo steps as the target (cost of secp256r1 signature verification on Starknet). Every optimization is measured against this.
    82â†’
    83â†’### The compiler
    84â†’Built on Day 3. A Python-to-Cairo compiler that takes arithmetic circuits and generates fully unrolled felt252 code. It tracks worst-case bounds internally, computes shifts, and uses BoundedInt only at final reductions (felt252 hybrid mode). This is the core technical advantage.
    85â†’
    86â†’### BoundedInt arc
    87â†’Day 2 introduced BoundedInt as the optimization. Day 3 built the compiler around it. Day 4 corrected Day 2 â€” using BoundedInt for every op overwhelmed the compiler; the hybrid mode is the real win. This correction is an honest, running narrative.
    88â†’
    89â†’### zknox collaboration
    90â†’@zknoxhq (@RenaudDUBOIS10, @SimonMasson2) built a Falcon NTT in Cairo independently. Found through @asanso's PQ Ethereum working group. Two teams, complementary work â€” they have Blake2s hash-to-point, we have the faster NTT.
    91â†’
    92â†’### 230k steps budget breakdown
    93â†’- NTT: 15,353 steps (7% of budget) â€” solved
    94â†’- Hash-to-point: Poseidon available now, Blake2s coming April (Starknet 0.14.2)
    95â†’- Full verification circuit: open question â€” will it fit under 230k?
    96â†’
    97â†’## Previous Threads Summary
    98â†’
    99â†’### Day 1
   100â†’Hook: "Quantum computers will eventually break every wallet on Ethereum."
   101â†’Content: Cloned s2morrow, benchmarked Falcon-512 at ~800k steps. Too much. Profiled, found secp256r1 costs ~230k â€” that's the target. "I have a theory on how to cut this in half. We'll see if I'm wrong tomorrow."
   102â†’
   103â†’### Day 2
   104â†’Hook: "I found a 65% overhead in the Falcon-512 verification. Not math related, it's just the CairoLang VM fighting itself. I've killed this pattern before and I'll do it again."
   105â†’Content: 65% overhead from store_temp, array ops, downcasts. Cut 20% with BoundedInt. Proposed bounded_int_circuit.py â€” a compiler for arithmetic circuits using BoundedInt. "The fix is to use one fully inlined function. Probably ~4000 lines."
   106â†’
   107â†’### Day 3
   108â†’Hook: "Making gangster progress. Turned an elegant NTT algorithm into a brutal 30k-line assembly file. It's nasty but 5x faster."
   109â†’Content: Built BoundedIntCircuit class. Generated NTT â€” 34,431 steps vs 185,992. Mentioned bytecode-steps tradeoff. "See you soon."
   110â†’
   111â†’### Day 4
   112â†’Hook: "Two teams independently wrote the same 10,000-line file. One runs 4x faster. The difference is one design decision."
   113â†’Content: Compared with zknox â€” shift strategy (every op vs once at end) and reduction width (u256 vs u128). BoundedInt correction (hybrid mode). Hash-to-point: skip rejection sampling via Falcon spec page 31. falcon-rs Rust port passing NIST test vectors. "If the whole thing comes in under 230k steps, we have a deployable post-quantum account contract for @Starknet. Let's see."
   114â†’
   115â†’## Open Threads for Day 5
   116â†’
   117â†’- Full Falcon verification circuit â€” does it fit under 230k?
   118â†’- Hash-to-point implementation with Poseidon
   119â†’- Account contract integration
   120â†’- Bytecode-steps tradeoff (mentioned Day 3, never resolved)
   121â†’- Blake2s integration when 0.14.2 drops
   122â†’

content.content:
1â†’# Gold Moments
     2â†’
     3â†’## Day 5 (Feb 11-12)
     4â†’
     5â†’### Breakthroughs
     6â†’- Built full Falcon verification pipeline in one afternoon: types, packing, hash-to-point, hint verify, cross-language tests â€” 15 commits between 15:10 and 21:04
     7â†’- Hash-to-point: 12 coefficients per felt252 via base-Q DivRem (3x more efficient than bit-limb approach)
     8â†’- poseidon_hash_span discovery: built-in does exactly what custom absorb did â€” replaced 20 lines with 1 function call â€” 33% gas reduction
     9â†’- Optimization sprint: 7 commits, 210k â†’ 132k steps (-37.3%) in one afternoon
    10â†’- Loop fusion trilogy: three commits, each merging more passes, ending with a single loop that does multiply + verify hint + subtract + compute both norms
    11â†’
    12â†’### Pain points
    13â†’- BoundedInt type chains: 40+ type definitions for packing alone, every bound computed by hand
    14â†’- Two separate DivRem chains needed for hash extraction (u128 vs FeltHigh bounds differ due to Stark prime)
    15â†’
    16â†’### Key numbers
    17â†’- Verify e2e: 210,888 â†’ 189,102 â†’ 173,693 â†’ 154,776 â†’ 147,070 â†’ 143,463 â†’ 132,152 steps
    18â†’- Packing: 512 Zq values â†’ 29 felt252 storage slots
    19â†’- Hash-to-point: 22 Poseidon permutations for 512 coefficients
    20â†’- Total reduction from Day 1: 800k â†’ 132k (-83.5%)
    21â†’
    22â†’### Claude sessions (Feb 11-12)
    23â†’- 93b550ca (26.9 MB, Feb 11 15:11) â€” Massive session: full prod-ready implementation
    24â†’- 24a3583e (9.3 MB, Feb 12 19:40) â€” Executing optimization plans
    25â†’- 5891aabe (7.6 MB, Feb 11 20:43) â€” Plan execution
    26â†’- 3bdd389e (462 KB, Feb 12 16:48) â€” Brainstorming session
    27â†’

content.content:
1â†’# Published Threads
     2â†’
     3â†’## Thread â€” Published 2025-05-23
     4â†’url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/1925856618027131321
     5â†’
     6â†’1/8
     7â†’Those 3 functions are equivalent Cairo code snippets that converts 4 32-bit limbs into a single u128 word.
     8â†’Can you guess which version is 47x more cost effective and why ? ðŸ§µ
     9â†’![](threads/media/post1_2f5edb27.png)
    10â†’
    11â†’2/8
    12â†’The first method converts (for free) the four u32 to u128 then perform arithmetic with u128 type. 
    13â†’This is the natural / immediate thing to do. 
    14â†’But safe u128 multiplications and aditions are costly! Checks are made for overflows even if we know it won't by construction.
    15â†’
    16â†’3/8
    17â†’The second one converts (for free) the 4 four u32 to felt252 then perform arithmetic with felt252 type.
    18â†’The arithmetic is then 1 step per addition or multiplication, because felt252 is Cairo's native type (for now) 
    19â†’But converting the felt252 result to u128 is costly again due to bound checks.
    20â†’
    21â†’4/8
    22â†’The third one uses more advanced capabilities of Cairo with bounded integers. 
    23â†’To use it, you need to implement the precise traits for additions and multiplications with the exact expected bounds. It allows to do safe predictable integer arithmetic with known bounds.
    24â†’
    25â†’5/8
    26â†’See the results ! The second one is 6.2x cheaper in gas than the first, and the third one is 47x cheaper!
    27â†’
    28â†’Notice how the third one doesn't use any range checks, because all bounds are controlled.
    29â†’
    30â†’In this case, the compiler will use felt252 arithmetic but won't need to bound check the final u128 conversion. Upcast is free.
    31â†’![](threads/media/post5_01c28f26.png)
    32â†’
    33â†’6/8
    34â†’Check this thread to understand more about the gas model.
    35â†’
    36â†’7/8
    37â†’Check the code on how to use BoundedInt for this case 
    38â†’https://github.com/feltroidprime/cairo-perfs-snippets/blob/main/src/u32_to_u128.cairo
    39â†’
    40â†’8/8
    41â†’Follow for more tips / don't hesitate to ask questions. ðŸ‘‹
    42â†’
    43â†’---
    44â†’
    45â†’## Day 1 â€” Published 2026-01-27
    46â†’url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2016231328065454142
    47â†’
    48â†’1/9
    49â†’[DAY 1] Quantum computers will eventually break every wallet on Ethereum. I'm going to build a performant post-quantum wallet using Falcon-512 signatures on @Starknet with Account Abstraction over the next few days, and I'll document every thought and struggle until delivery.
    50â†’
    51â†’2/9
    52â†’A side goal is to create as many Claude skills as possible so I can replicate myself in markdown files.
    53â†’
    54â†’3/9
    55â†’I'm starting first by cloning https://github.com/starkware-bitcoin/s2morrow, a PoC for post-quantum signature verification in Cairo, and immediately benchmarking Falcon-512.
    56â†’
    57â†’4/9
    58â†’This is typically the kind of process I'd like to create a skill for. 
    59â†’
    60â†’We should be able to easily transform the multiples, long and verbose command lines needed to just asking Claude 
    61â†’
    62â†’"profile the falcon-512 verification by cairo steps and save it to a .png file"
    63â†’
    64â†’5/9
    65â†’I used the writing-skills skill from this awesome repo https://github.com/obra/superpowers/tree/main/skills/writing-skills and after a few iterations i made my own skill for it : https://github.com/feltroidprime/cairo-skills/tree/main ! 
    66â†’
    67â†’Many more skills for Cairo & Starknet coming ! Might become the official agentic way to build on Starknet ;)
    68â†’
    69â†’6/9
    70â†’Ok the skill worked well !
    71â†’![](threads/day1/media/post6_65a77934.png)
    72â†’![](threads/day1/media/post6_1cd22a28.png)
    73â†’
    74â†’7/9
    75â†’We can see ~800k Cairo steps for a verification... 
    76â†’
    77â†’This is definitely too much. I've profiled so many Cairo functions and worked with falcon sig in Cairo previously and I just know it's too much. 
    78â†’ 
    79â†’I wanted to use the Cairo skill I've just created to compare it to something else (secp256r1 sig verif) ðŸ˜Ž
    80â†’![](threads/day1/media/post7_0414efac.png)
    81â†’
    82â†’8/9
    83â†’Well, turns out this didn't worked well but not because of the Skill...
    84â†’
    85â†’The Cairo profiler missed to report the cost of internal functions. 
    86â†’
    87â†’Fortunately I knew the expected order of magnitude and created an issue https://github.com/software-mansion/cairo-profiler/issues/239
    88â†’
    89â†’let's hope this get fixed soon
    90â†’
    91â†’9/9
    92â†’But doesn't prevent us to know the cost with some extra steps: around 230k cairo steps for secp256r1. 
    93â†’That's now my target for Falcon. I'm pretty confident we can beat it. 
    94â†’I have a theory on how to cut this in half. We'll see if I'm wrong tomorrow.
    95â†’
    96â†’---
    97â†’
    98â†’## Day 2 â€” Published 2026-01-28
    99â†’url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2016632991892853245
   100â†’
   101â†’1/11
   102â†’[DAY 2] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet.
   103â†’I found a 65% overhead in the Falcon-512 verification.
   104â†’Not math related, it's just the @CairoLang VM fighting itself.
   105â†’I've killed this pattern before and I'll do it again.
   106â†’
   107â†’2/11
   108â†’store_temp, array_snapshot_pop_front, downcast, array_append, totaling 65.24% of the cost. 
   109â†’Nothing quantum here ðŸ˜†
   110â†’![](threads/day2/media/post2_26c9dbfb.png)
   111â†’
   112â†’3/11
   113â†’I already cut 20% using Bounded Ints, a primitive that lets you skip overflow checks when you can prove bounds at compile time.
   114â†’Most efficient way to do arithmetic in Cairo. I believe at most 2 people outside Starkware are using it, not even exaggerating.
   115â†’
   116â†’4/11
   117â†’Bounded Ints are so hidden inside the Cairo corelib that I had to create a package using the old 2023_10 edition just to re-export private functions.
   118â†’https://scarbs.xyz/packages/corelib_imports
   119â†’
   120â†’5/11
   121â†’They're also painful to use. You need to implement traits with exact input and output bounds for every operation.
   122â†’If you make any mistake the compiler crashes. No useful error, just death.
   123â†’![](threads/day2/media/post5_014981df.png)
   124â†’
   125â†’6/11
   126â†’I created a Skill so Claude could generate bounded int implementations for me. But anything deterministic shouldn't be deferred to an agent, both to avoid errors and useless token usage. So I also asked him to make a Python CLI to compute the bounds.
   127â†’https://github.com/feltroidprime/cairo-skills/blob/main/using-bounded-int
   128â†’
   129â†’7/11
   130â†’So 20% down from yesterday, but Bounded ints won't remove the 65% overhead left.
   131â†’Falcon verification uses NTT multiplication, a recursive, divide and conquer algo. In Cairo this implies function calls, data copying, and array creation.
   132â†’None of that is math. All of it costs.
   133â†’
   134â†’8/11
   135â†’The fix is to use one fully inlined function. Probably ~4000 lines. 
   136â†’All arithmetic operations directly over variables, hardcoded constants within the function. No arrays, no recursion, no "if-else", no data copying, no abstraction over the size of the signature.... ðŸ˜´ 
   137â†’Pure computation signal. 
   138â†’I love these kind of files :D
   139â†’![](threads/day2/media/post8_6eb50c07.png)
   140â†’
   141â†’9/11
   142â†’In @GaragaStarknet, I built a Python-to-Cairo compiler "modulo_circuit.py" for arithmetic circuits over emulated (large) integers in this file https://github.com/keep-starknet-strange/garaga/blob/main/hydra/garaga/modulo_circuit.py
   143â†’
   144â†’It'll be the same idea here. 
   145â†’
   146â†’Except that we'll compile the Falcon verification to an arithmetic circuit using Bounded Ints (small integers). 
   147â†’Probably bounded_int_circuit.py ?
   148â†’
   149â†’10/11
   150â†’Externalizing myself in .md files is harder than expected. When optimizing Cairo programs I take decisions at a subconscious level. The reasoning is deeper than I thought.
   151â†’More Skills to refine.
   152â†’
   153â†’11/11
   154â†’So next up: bounded_int_circuit.py
   155â†’A compiler that turns any arithmetic circuit into pure bounded int operations.
   156â†’Then we'll be able to build a quantum wallet that scales.
   157â†’
   158â†’---
   159â†’
   160â†’## Day 3 â€” Published 2026-01-30
   161â†’url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2017277443510514149
   162â†’
   163â†’1/9
   164â†’[DAY 3] of building a Quantum wallet of @Starknet 
   165â†’Making gangster progress. Turned an elegant NTT algorithm into a brutal 30k-line assembly file.
   166â†’It's nasty but 5x faster.
   167â†’
   168â†’2/9
   169â†’I asked Claude to create a BoundedIntCircuit class, taking inspiration from what I've did in Garaga at the time. You define the initial bounds and the sequence of operations in Python and it will generate a Cairo function with all the correct bounds implementations.
   170â†’![](threads/day3/media/post2_b176babb.png)
   171â†’![](threads/day3/media/post2_62b37ca5.png)
   172â†’
   173â†’3/9
   174â†’Then I asked him to define a BoundedIntCircuit for a NTT of size 512.
   175â†’The generated file is crazy at this point ðŸ˜† but exactly how I like them.
   176â†’![](threads/day3/media/post3_93f2216f.mp4)
   177â†’
   178â†’4/9
   179â†’The results speak for themselves. The fully inlined bounded int version of the NTT takes 34 431 Cairo Steps vs 185 992 for the previous version. 
   180â†’That's a -81.4% reduction !
   181â†’![](threads/day3/media/post4_e7985142.png)
   182â†’
   183â†’5/9
   184â†’To verify the full Falcon signature, more work needs to be done, but NTT was the base brick. This validates the BoundedInt compiler flow and value for a core part of the signature verification.
   185â†’![](threads/day3/media/post5_55cf4b33.png)
   186â†’
   187â†’6/9
   188â†’Before jumping into creating the circuits for mul_ntt, intt, sub_zq, and the norm computation, I'd like to refine my Cairo Agentic Setup to enhance my Cairo/Starknet workflow. Claude unnecessary slow to converge due to silly things in cairo tooling.
   189â†’
   190â†’7/9
   191â†’Additionally, I'm not sure what is the size of the compiled bytecode size, if it's too large for Starknet, I might need to break down the ntt circuit in smaller parts at the cost of a small overhead, to find a sweet spot. 
   192â†’I call this the "bytecode-steps trade-off"
   193â†’
   194â†’8/9
   195â†’So, it's time to spend 1 or 2 full days to upgrade my Cairo Agentic setup. I want it to become ultra smooth, using the right skills, hooks, session starts hooks and more. This will benefit all Cairo community.
   196â†’
   197â†’9/9
   198â†’See you soon.
   199â†’
   200â†’---
   201â†’
   202â†’## Day 4 â€” Published 2026-02-10
   203â†’url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2021250459210743914
   204â†’
   205â†’1/11
   206â†’[DAY 4] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet. Two teams independently wrote the same 10,000-line file. Same algorithm, same language, same brutal unrolled approach. One runs 4x faster. The difference is one subtle design decision.
   207â†’
   208â†’That 4x puts Falcon verification under the 230k steps target from Day 1.
   209â†’
   210â†’2/11
   211â†’I found them through @asanso's post-quantum Ethereum working group with @drakefjustin and @tcoratger. @RenaudDUBOIS10 and @SimonMasson2 from @zknoxhq built a Falcon NTT in Cairo too â€” fully inlined, no arrays, no function calls. I assumed similar performance and had to benchmark it.
   212â†’
   213â†’3/11
   214â†’Both implementations unroll the NTT into ~10k lines of raw felt252 arithmetic. The first difference is how they handle negative intermediates from butterfly operations. zknox shifts every subtraction back to positive immediately; I let values go negative through all 9 stages and shift once at the end.
   215â†’![](threads/day4/media/post3_61b2b2a3.png)
   216â†’
   217â†’4/11
   218â†’The second difference is reduction. zknox reduces from u256. The compiler I built on Day 3 tracks bounds through the whole circuit and knows the max value is 122 bits â€” it fits in u128, which is way cheaper to reduce in Cairo. This is where most of the 4x comes from.
   219â†’![](threads/day4/media/post4_27a038bc.png)
   220â†’
   221â†’5/11
   222â†’A correction from Day 2 on BoundedInt: using it for every operation actually overwhelmed the compiler at this scale. The compiler still tracks worst-case bounds internally, so it knows when overflow checks are unnecessary and computes the exact shift needed to bring negative values back to positive. I added a felt252 hybrid mode where arithmetic stays in felt252 and BoundedInt kicks in only at the final div_mod reductions. Same win, less pressure on the compiler.
   223â†’
   224â†’6/11
   225â†’15,353 steps â€” down from 34k on Day 3 and 185k on Day 2. The NTT was supposed to be the bottleneck; it's only 7% of the verification budget now. ðŸš€
   226â†’![](threads/day4/media/post6_80863c0a.png)
   227â†’
   228â†’7/11
   229â†’NTT is done; next problem is hashing. Falcon hashes a message into 512 coefficients mod 12289, and the spec uses SHAKE256, but that's way too expensive in Cairo. Blake2s would be ideal â€” it's a native opcode and 2-3x cheaper than Poseidon. I asked @Starkware eng. team, and it won't be available to contracts until Starknet 0.14.2 in April. So Poseidon it is for now.
   230â†’
   231â†’8/11
   232â†’The standard hash-to-point uses rejection sampling: you extract 16 bits, reject biased values, and retry. That's a 6% rejection rate and requires branching. I was about to implement it, then looked at how @0xMiden does their Falcon with Poseidon2. They skip rejection entirely.
   233â†’
   234â†’The trick is in the Falcon spec itself (page 31): if your hash output is much larger than q, you can extract more bits and reduce directly. The minimum needed is >~50 bits for q at 14 bits. You skip rejection, branching, and retries entirely.
   235â†’
   236â†’9/11
   237â†’@zknoxhq already built a great Blake2s hash-to-point for Falcon in Cairo â€” about 34 calls for 512 coefficients. Once 0.14.2 lands, we'll integrate it.  
   238â†’https://github.com/ZKNoxHQ/falzkon/blob/main/contracts/src/blake2s_hash.cairo
   239â†’
   240â†’10/11
   241â†’I'm building the client side too. Rust port of Falcon-512 with a generic hash trait. Keygen, signing, and verification all pass NIST's 100 known-answer test vectors. This will become the WASM signer for browser or mobile wallets. https://github.com/feltroidprime/falcon-rs
   242â†’
   243â†’11/11
   244â†’The NTT costs 15k steps and the hash pipeline is ready. Next I'm wiring them into an actual account contract â€” a wallet on @Starknet that signs with Falcon-512. Let's go!
   245â†’
   246â†’---
   247â†’

1â†’"""
     2â†’Generate visual assets for a Twitter thread comparing two NTT implementations.
     3â†’
     4â†’Produces three images:
     5â†’  1. ntt_comparison_code.png  -- Side-by-side syntax-highlighted code
     6â†’  2. ntt_comparison_bars.png  -- Step count bar chart
     7â†’  3. ntt_shift_diagram.png    -- Architecture flow diagram
     8â†’
     9â†’Usage:
    10â†’    python scripts/thread_visuals.py
    11â†’"""
    12â†’
    13â†’from __future__ import annotations
    14â†’
    15â†’import os
    16â†’import re
    17â†’from pathlib import Path
    18â†’
    19â†’import matplotlib
    20â†’matplotlib.use("Agg")
    21â†’
    22â†’import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
    23â†’import matplotlib.patches as mpatches
    24â†’from matplotlib.patches import FancyBboxPatch, FancyArrowPatch
    25â†’import matplotlib.patheffects as pe
    26â†’import numpy as np
    27â†’
    28â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    29â†’# Global palette (Tokyo Night inspired)
    30â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    31â†’BG = "#1a1b26"
    32â†’BG_PANEL = "#24283b"
    33â†’FG = "#c0caf5"
    34â†’COMMENT = "#565f89"
    35â†’KEYWORD = "#bb9af7"   # purple
    36â†’TYPE = "#7dcfff"       # cyan
    37â†’NUMBER = "#ff9e64"     # orange
    38â†’STRING = "#9ece6a"     # green
    39â†’OPERATOR = "#89ddff"   # light cyan
    40â†’ACCENT_GREEN = "#9ece6a"
    41â†’ACCENT_CYAN = "#7dcfff"
    42â†’ACCENT_RED = "#f7768e"
    43â†’ACCENT_ORANGE = "#ff9e64"
    44â†’WHITE = "#ffffff"
    45â†’DIM_WHITE = "#a9b1d6"
    46â†’SEPARATOR = "#3b4261"
    47â†’
    48â†’MONO = "DejaVu Sans Mono"
    49â†’SANS = "DejaVu Sans"
    50â†’
    51â†’OUTPUT_DIR = Path(__file__).resolve().parent / "thread_output"
    52â†’DPI = 200
    53â†’
    54â†’
    55â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    56â†’# Helpers
    57â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    58â†’
    59â†’def _setup_style():
    60â†’    plt.style.use("dark_background")
    61â†’    plt.rcParams.update({
    62â†’        "figure.facecolor": BG,
    63â†’        "axes.facecolor": BG,
    64â†’        "savefig.facecolor": BG,
    65â†’        "text.color": FG,
    66â†’        "font.family": "sans-serif",
    67â†’        "font.sans-serif": [SANS],
    68â†’    })
    69â†’
    70â†’
    71â†’def _syntax_color(line: str) -> list[tuple[str, str]]:
    72â†’    """Return a list of (text, color) spans for a single Cairo-like line."""
    73â†’    spans: list[tuple[str, str]] = []
    74â†’
    75â†’    if not line.strip():
    76â†’        return [("", FG)]
    77â†’
    78â†’    # Full-line comment
    79â†’    stripped = line.lstrip()
    80â†’    if stripped.startswith("//"):
    81â†’        return [(line, COMMENT)]
    82â†’
    83â†’    KEYWORDS = {"let", "fn", "type", "const", "use", "return", "pub", "mod", "impl", "trait"}
    84â†’    TYPES = {
    85â†’        "felt252", "u256", "u128", "u64", "u32", "ShiftedT", "BoundedInt",
    86â†’        "Qshift", "Q256", "SHIFT",
    87â†’    }
    88â†’
    89â†’    i = 0
    90â†’    text = line
    91â†’    while i < len(text):
    92â†’        # Inline comment
    93â†’        if text[i:i+2] == "//":
    94â†’            spans.append((text[i:], COMMENT))
    95â†’            break
    96â†’
    97â†’        # Whitespace
    98â†’        if text[i] in " \t":
    99â†’            j = i
   100â†’            while j < len(text) and text[j] in " \t":
   101â†’                j += 1
   102â†’            spans.append((text[i:j], FG))
   103â†’            i = j
   104â†’            continue
   105â†’
   106â†’        # Numbers
   107â†’        if text[i].isdigit():
   108â†’            j = i
   109â†’            while j < len(text) and (text[j].isdigit() or text[j] in "._"):
   110â†’                j += 1
   111â†’            spans.append((text[i:j], NUMBER))
   112â†’            i = j
   113â†’            continue
   114â†’
   115â†’        # Operators / punctuation
   116â†’        if text[i] in "=+-*/%<>(){}[];:,.!&|^":
   117â†’            # Multi-char operators
   118â†’            two = text[i:i+2]
   119â†’            if two in ("->", "=>", "!=", "==", "<=", ">=", "&&", "||"):
   120â†’                spans.append((two, OPERATOR))
   121â†’                i += 2
   122â†’                continue
   123â†’            spans.append((text[i], OPERATOR))
   124â†’            i += 1
   125â†’            continue
   126â†’
   127â†’        # Words (identifiers, keywords, types)
   128â†’        if text[i].isalpha() or text[i] == "_":
   129â†’            j = i
   130â†’            while j < len(text) and (text[j].isalnum() or text[j] == "_"):
   131â†’                j += 1
   132â†’            word = text[i:j]
   133â†’            if word in KEYWORDS:
   134â†’                spans.append((word, KEYWORD))
   135â†’            elif word in TYPES:
   136â†’                spans.append((word, TYPE))
   137â†’            elif word == "nz_q":
   138â†’                spans.append((word, TYPE))
   139â†’            else:
   140â†’                spans.append((word, FG))
   141â†’            i = j
   142â†’            continue
   143â†’
   144â†’        # Fallback
   145â†’        spans.append((text[i], FG))
   146â†’        i += 1
   147â†’
   148â†’    return spans
   149â†’
   150â†’
   151â†’def _draw_syntax_line(ax, x: float, y: float, line: str, fontsize: float = 9.5):
   152â†’    """Draw a single syntax-highlighted line on an axes at (x, y) in axes coords."""
   153â†’    spans = _syntax_color(line)
   154â†’    offset = 0
   155â†’    for text_chunk, color in spans:
   156â†’        if not text_chunk:
   157â†’            continue
   158â†’        t = ax.text(
   159â†’            x + offset, y, text_chunk,
   160â†’            fontfamily=MONO, fontsize=fontsize, color=color,
   161â†’            transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment="top",
   162â†’            fontweight="normal",
   163â†’        )
   164â†’        # Estimate character width (monospace)
   165â†’        offset += len(text_chunk) * 0.0138
   166â†’
   167â†’
   168â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   169â†’# Image 1: Code comparison
   170â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   171â†’
   172â†’LEFT_CODE = """\
   173â†’// Butterfly: shift after every subtraction
   174â†’let Qshift: felt252 = 12289 * 16384;
   175â†’let a = U + V;
   176â†’let b = U + Qshift - V;  // shift to stay positive
   177â†’
   178â†’// ... 9 stages of butterflies ...
   179â†’
   180â†’// Final reduction: cast to u256
   181â†’fn reduc256(a: felt252) -> felt252 {
   182â†’    let v: u256 = a.into();
   183â†’    let r = v % Q256;
   184â†’    r.try_into().unwrap()
   185â†’}"""
   186â†’
   187â†’RIGHT_CODE = """\
   188â†’// Butterfly: allow negative intermediates
   189â†’let a = U + V;
   190â†’let b = U - V;  // can go negative, that's fine
   191â†’
   192â†’// ... 9 stages of butterflies ...
   193â†’
   194â†’// Final reduction: bounds-aware u128
   195â†’// Compiler knows max value fits in 122 bits
   196â†’type ShiftedT = BoundedInt<0, 4612...806>;
   197â†’let r: ShiftedT = (tmp + SHIFT).try_into().unwrap();
   198â†’let (_, rem) = bounded_int_div_rem(r, nz_q);"""
   199â†’
   200â†’
   201â†’def generate_code_comparison():
   202â†’    fig = plt.figure(figsize=(16, 6.5), dpi=DPI)
   203â†’    fig.patch.set_facecolor(BG)
   204â†’
   205â†’    # Two panels
   206â†’    ax_left = fig.add_axes([0.02, 0.02, 0.47, 0.82])
   207â†’    ax_right = fig.add_axes([0.51, 0.02, 0.47, 0.82])
   208â†’
   209â†’    for ax in (ax_left, ax_right):
   210â†’        ax.set_xlim(0, 1)
   211â†’        ax.set_ylim(0, 1)
   212â†’        ax.axis("off")
   213â†’        ax.set_facecolor(BG_PANEL)
   214â†’        # Draw panel background
   215â†’        rect = FancyBboxPatch(
   216â†’            (0, 0), 1, 1,
   217â†’            boxstyle="round,pad=0.02",
   218â†’            facecolor=BG_PANEL, edgecolor=SEPARATOR, linewidth=1.5,
   219â†’            transform=ax.transAxes, zorder=0,
   220â†’        )
   221â†’        ax.add_patch(rect)
   222â†’
   223â†’    # Separator line
   224â†’    fig.patches.append(mpatches.FancyBboxPatch(
   225â†’        (0.492, 0.04), 0.004, 0.80,
   226â†’        boxstyle="round,pad=0.002",
   227â†’        facecolor=SEPARATOR, edgecolor="none",
   228â†’        transform=fig.transFigure, zorder=5,
   229â†’    ))
   230â†’
   231â†’    # Titles
   232â†’    fig.text(0.255, 0.95, "zknox approach", fontsize=22, fontweight="bold",
   233â†’             color=WHITE, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS)
   234â†’    fig.text(0.255, 0.90, "Shift every butterfly  ->  reduce from u256", fontsize=12,
   235â†’             color=ACCENT_ORANGE, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS, style="italic")
   236â†’
   237â†’    fig.text(0.745, 0.95, "Our approach", fontsize=22, fontweight="bold",
   238â†’             color=WHITE, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS)
   239â†’    fig.text(0.745, 0.90, "Allow negatives  ->  shift once  ->  reduce from u128", fontsize=12,
   240â†’             color=ACCENT_GREEN, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS, style="italic")
   241â†’
   242â†’    # Draw code
   243â†’    left_lines = LEFT_CODE.split("\n")
   244â†’    right_lines = RIGHT_CODE.split("\n")
   245â†’
   246â†’    line_height = 0.068
   247â†’    start_y = 0.92
   248â†’
   249â†’    for i, line in enumerate(left_lines):
   250â†’        _draw_syntax_line(ax_left, 0.04, start_y - i * line_height, line, fontsize=10.5)
   251â†’
   252â†’    for i, line in enumerate(right_lines):
   253â†’        _draw_syntax_line(ax_right, 0.04, start_y - i * line_height, line, fontsize=10.5)
   254â†’
   255â†’    # Bottom badge / "vs" label
   256â†’    fig.text(0.5, 0.005, "Falcon NTT-512 on Starknet", fontsize=11,
   257â†’             color=COMMENT, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS)
   258â†’
   259â†’    out = OUTPUT_DIR / "ntt_comparison_code.png"
   260â†’    fig.savefig(out, dpi=DPI, bbox_inches="tight", pad_inches=0.15)
   261â†’    plt.close(fig)
   262â†’    print(f"  Saved {out}")
   263â†’
   264â†’
   265â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   266â†’# Image 2: Bar chart
   267â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   268â†’
   269â†’def generate_bar_chart():
   270â†’    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 6), dpi=DPI)
   271â†’    fig.patch.set_facecolor(BG)
   272â†’    ax.set_facecolor(BG)
   273â†’
   274â†’    # Data â€” NTT function steps only (child nodes included in parent)
   275â†’    zknox_steps = 63_479
   276â†’    ours_total = 15_353
   277â†’    secp256r1_baseline = 230_000
   278â†’
   279â†’    speedup = zknox_steps / ours_total
   280â†’
   281â†’    bar_height = 0.45
   282â†’    y_positions = [1.0, 0.35]
   283â†’
   284â†’    # zknox bar
   285â†’    ax.barh(
   286â†’        y_positions[0], zknox_steps, height=bar_height,
   287â†’        color=ACCENT_RED, edgecolor="none", alpha=0.9,
   288â†’        label="zknox (u256 reduce)", zorder=3,
   289â†’    )
   290â†’    ax.text(
   291â†’        zknox_steps + 2500, y_positions[0], f"{zknox_steps:,} steps",
   292â†’        va="center", ha="left", fontsize=14, fontweight="bold",
   293â†’        color=ACCENT_RED, fontfamily=SANS,
   294â†’    )
   295â†’
   296â†’    # Ours bar
   297â†’    ax.barh(
   298â†’        y_positions[1], ours_total, height=bar_height,
   299â†’        color=ACCENT_GREEN, edgecolor="none", alpha=0.9, zorder=3,
   300â†’    )
   301â†’    ax.text(
   302â†’        ours_total + 2500, y_positions[1], f"{ours_total:,} steps",
   303â†’        va="center", ha="left", fontsize=14, fontweight="bold",
   304â†’        color=ACCENT_GREEN, fontfamily=SANS,
   305â†’    )
   306â†’
   307â†’    # Y labels
   308â†’    ax.set_yticks(y_positions)
   309â†’    ax.set_yticklabels(
   310â†’        ["zknox\n(u256 reduce)", "Ours\n(u128 reduce)"],
   311â†’        fontsize=13, fontweight="bold", fontfamily=SANS,
   312â†’    )
   313â†’
   314â†’    # "4.1x faster" annotation
   315â†’    ax.annotate(
   316â†’        "",
   317â†’        xy=(ours_total + 1000, y_positions[1] + 0.24),
   318â†’        xytext=(zknox_steps - 1000, y_positions[0] - 0.24),
   319â†’        arrowprops=dict(
   320â†’            arrowstyle="->,head_width=0.4,head_length=0.3",
   321â†’            color=ACCENT_GREEN, lw=2.5,
   322â†’            connectionstyle="arc3,rad=-0.2",

1â†’"""
     2â†’Generate visual assets for Day 5 Twitter thread.
     3â†’
     4â†’Produces three images:
     5â†’  1. day5_verify_flow.png       -- Standard vs hint-based verification flow
     6â†’  2. day5_extraction_chain.png  -- Base-Q DivRem extraction from felt252
     7â†’  3. day5_optimization_waterfall.png -- Optimization sprint waterfall chart
     8â†’
     9â†’Usage:
    10â†’    python scripts/thread/visuals/day5_visuals.py
    11â†’"""
    12â†’
    13â†’from __future__ import annotations
    14â†’
    15â†’from pathlib import Path
    16â†’
    17â†’import matplotlib
    18â†’matplotlib.use("Agg")
    19â†’
    20â†’import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
    21â†’from matplotlib.patches import FancyBboxPatch
    22â†’import numpy as np
    23â†’
    24â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    25â†’# Global palette (Tokyo Night inspired â€” shared with thread_visuals.py)
    26â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    27â†’BG = "#1a1b26"
    28â†’BG_PANEL = "#24283b"
    29â†’FG = "#c0caf5"
    30â†’COMMENT = "#565f89"
    31â†’KEYWORD = "#bb9af7"   # purple
    32â†’TYPE = "#7dcfff"       # cyan
    33â†’NUMBER = "#ff9e64"     # orange
    34â†’STRING = "#9ece6a"     # green
    35â†’OPERATOR = "#89ddff"   # light cyan
    36â†’ACCENT_GREEN = "#9ece6a"
    37â†’ACCENT_CYAN = "#7dcfff"
    38â†’ACCENT_RED = "#f7768e"
    39â†’ACCENT_ORANGE = "#ff9e64"
    40â†’WHITE = "#ffffff"
    41â†’DIM_WHITE = "#a9b1d6"
    42â†’SEPARATOR = "#3b4261"
    43â†’
    44â†’MONO = "DejaVu Sans Mono"
    45â†’SANS = "DejaVu Sans"
    46â†’
    47â†’OUTPUT_DIR = Path(__file__).resolve().parent / "day5_output"
    48â†’DPI = 200
    49â†’
    50â†’
    51â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    52â†’# Helpers (same as thread_visuals.py)
    53â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    54â†’
    55â†’def _setup_style():
    56â†’    plt.style.use("dark_background")
    57â†’    plt.rcParams.update({
    58â†’        "figure.facecolor": BG,
    59â†’        "axes.facecolor": BG,
    60â†’        "savefig.facecolor": BG,
    61â†’        "text.color": FG,
    62â†’        "font.family": "sans-serif",
    63â†’        "font.sans-serif": [SANS],
    64â†’    })
    65â†’
    66â†’
    67â†’def _draw_box(ax, cx, cy, w, h, text, facecolor=BG_PANEL, edgecolor=SEPARATOR,
    68â†’              textcolor=FG, fontsize=9, bold=False, fontfamily=None, alpha=1.0):
    69â†’    """Draw a rounded box centered at (cx, cy) with text inside."""
    70â†’    rect = FancyBboxPatch(
    71â†’        (cx - w / 2, cy - h / 2), w, h,
    72â†’        boxstyle="round,pad=0.012",
    73â†’        facecolor=facecolor, edgecolor=edgecolor, linewidth=1.5,
    74â†’        transform=ax.transData, zorder=3, alpha=alpha,
    75â†’    )
    76â†’    ax.add_patch(rect)
    77â†’    ax.text(
    78â†’        cx, cy, text, fontsize=fontsize, color=textcolor,
    79â†’        ha="center", va="center", fontfamily=fontfamily or SANS,
    80â†’        fontweight="bold" if bold else "normal", zorder=4,
    81â†’        linespacing=1.3,
    82â†’    )
    83â†’    return rect
    84â†’
    85â†’
    86â†’def _draw_arrow(ax, x1, y1, x2, y2, color=SEPARATOR, lw=1.5):
    87â†’    """Draw an arrow from (x1,y1) to (x2,y2)."""
    88â†’    ax.annotate(
    89â†’        "", xy=(x2, y2), xytext=(x1, y1),
    90â†’        arrowprops=dict(
    91â†’            arrowstyle="->,head_width=0.15,head_length=0.1",
    92â†’            color=color, lw=lw, shrinkA=0, shrinkB=0,
    93â†’        ),
    94â†’        zorder=2,
    95â†’    )
    96â†’
    97â†’
    98â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    99â†’# Image 1: Verification flow â€” Standard vs Hint-based
   100â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   101â†’
   102â†’def generate_verify_flow():
   103â†’    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(16, 7), dpi=DPI)
   104â†’    fig.patch.set_facecolor(BG)
   105â†’    ax.set_facecolor(BG)
   106â†’    ax.set_xlim(0, 11)
   107â†’    ax.set_ylim(0, 5.5)
   108â†’    ax.axis("off")
   109â†’
   110â†’    # Title
   111â†’    fig.text(0.5, 0.95, "Verification: Standard vs Hint-Based",
   112â†’             fontsize=22, fontweight="bold", color=WHITE, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS)
   113â†’
   114â†’    # --- Shared box parameters ---
   115â†’    bw = 0.95
   116â†’    bh = 0.55
   117â†’    arrow_col = "#545c7e"

   119â†’    # =====================================================================
   120â†’    # TOP ROW  (Standard) â€” y = 3.8
   121â†’    # =====================================================================
   122â†’    y_top = 3.8
   123â†’
   124â†’    ax.text(0.25, y_top, "Standard", fontsize=16, fontweight="bold", color=ACCENT_RED,
   125â†’            ha="center", va="center", fontfamily=SANS)
   126â†’
   127â†’    boxes_top = [
   128â†’        (1.5, "NTT(s1)", "#2d1a1a", ACCENT_RED, ACCENT_ORANGE),

   190â†’
   191â†’    # Arrows bottom
   192â†’    arrow_pairs_bot = [(2.0, 2.4), (3.4, 4.1), (5.1, 5.5), (6.5, 6.9)]

   209â†’    ax.annotate(

   219â†’    # --- Horizontal separator ---

   234â†’
   235â†’
   236â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   237â†’# Image 2: Base-Q extraction chain
   238â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   239â†’
   240â†’def generate_extraction_chain():
   241â†’    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 9), dpi=DPI)
   242â†’    fig.patch.set_facecolor(BG)
   243â†’    ax.set_facecolor(BG)
   244â†’    ax.set_xlim(0, 10)
   245â†’    ax.set_ylim(0, 10)
   246â†’    ax.axis("off")
   247â†’
   248â†’    # Title
   249â†’    fig.text(0.5, 0.96, "Base-Q Extraction: felt252 to Zq Coefficients",
   250â†’             fontsize=22, fontweight="bold", color=WHITE, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS)
   251â†’
   252â†’    # --- Top: felt252 ---
   253â†’    _draw_box(ax, 5.0, 9.0, 3.5, 0.65, "felt252  (251 bits)",
   254â†’              facecolor=BG_PANEL, edgecolor=ACCENT_CYAN, textcolor=ACCENT_CYAN,
   255â†’              fontsize=13, bold=True)
   256â†’
   257â†’    # Split arrow down
   258â†’    _draw_arrow(ax, 5.0, 8.65, 5.0, 8.15, color=DIM_WHITE, lw=2)
   259â†’    ax.text(5.6, 8.4, "split", fontsize=10, color=DIM_WHITE, ha="left",
   260â†’            fontfamily=SANS, style="italic")
   261â†’
   262â†’    # --- Two branches ---
   263â†’    # Left: u128
   264â†’    left_x = 3.0
   265â†’    _draw_box(ax, left_x, 7.8, 2.5, 0.55, "u128  (128 bits)",
   266â†’              facecolor=BG_PANEL, edgecolor=ACCENT_CYAN, textcolor=ACCENT_CYAN,
   267â†’              fontsize=11, bold=True)
   268â†’
   269â†’    # Right: FeltHigh
   270â†’    right_x = 7.0
   271â†’    _draw_box(ax, right_x, 7.8, 2.5, 0.55, "FeltHigh  (124 bits)",
   272â†’              facecolor=BG_PANEL, edgecolor=ACCENT_ORANGE, textcolor=ACCENT_ORANGE,
   273â†’              fontsize=11, bold=True)
   274â†’
   275â†’    # Fork arrows from split point
   276â†’    _draw_arrow(ax, 4.2, 8.1, left_x + 0.3, 8.1, color=DIM_WHITE, lw=1.5)
   277â†’    _draw_arrow(ax, 5.8, 8.1, right_x - 0.3, 8.1, color=DIM_WHITE, lw=1.5)
   278â†’
   279â†’    # --- DivRem chains ---
   280â†’    divrem_y_start = 7.15
   281â†’    divrem_step = 0.72
   282â†’
   283â†’    for branch_x, branch_color, branch_label, bits_left, discard_bits in [
   284â†’        (left_x, ACCENT_CYAN, "u128", 128, 47),
   285â†’        (right_x, ACCENT_ORANGE, "FeltHigh", 124, 42),
   286â†’    ]:
   287â†’        for i in range(6):
   288â†’            y = divrem_y_start - i * divrem_step
   289â†’            remaining = bits_left - (i + 1) * 14  # ~14 bits per q
   290â†’
   291â†’            # DivRem box
   292â†’            box_label = f"DivRem-by-q #{i+1}"
   293â†’            _draw_box(ax, branch_x, y, 2.2, 0.45, box_label,
   294â†’                      facecolor="#1a2420" if branch_color == ACCENT_CYAN else "#2d2a1a",
   295â†’                      edgecolor=branch_color, textcolor=branch_color,
   296â†’                      fontsize=8.5, bold=False)
   297â†’
   298â†’            # Coefficient output arrow (right side)
   299â†’            coeff_x = branch_x + 1.4
   300â†’            ax.text(coeff_x, y, f"\u2192 Zq", fontsize=8, color=ACCENT_GREEN,
   301â†’                    ha="left", va="center", fontfamily=MONO, fontweight="bold")
   302â†’
   303â†’            # Arrow to next step
   304â†’            if i < 5:
   305â†’                _draw_arrow(ax, branch_x, y - 0.23, branch_x, y - 0.49,
   306â†’                            color="#545c7e")
   307â†’
   308â†’        # Discard remainder
   309â†’        y_discard = divrem_y_start - 6 * divrem_step + 0.1
   310â†’        discard_rect = FancyBboxPatch(
   311â†’            (branch_x - 1.1, y_discard - 0.22), 2.2, 0.38,
   312â†’            boxstyle="round,pad=0.01",
   313â†’            facecolor=ACCENT_RED, edgecolor="none", alpha=0.12,
   314â†’            transform=ax.transData, zorder=1,
   315â†’        )
   316â†’        ax.add_patch(discard_rect)
   317â†’        ax.text(branch_x, y_discard, f"remainder ({discard_bits} bits)\ndiscarded",
   318â†’                fontsize=8, color=ACCENT_RED, ha="center", va="center",
   319â†’                fontfamily=SANS, style="italic", alpha=0.9)
   320â†’
   321â†’    # --- Bottom summary ---
   322â†’    ax.text(5.0, 1.6,
   323â†’            "12 coefficients per felt252",
   324â†’            fontsize=14, color=WHITE, ha="center", va="center",
   325â†’            fontfamily=SANS, fontweight="bold")
   326â†’    ax.text(5.0, 1.1,
   327â†’            "22 Poseidon permutations = 512+ coefficients",
   328â†’            fontsize=12, color=DIM_WHITE, ha="center", va="center",
   329â†’            fontfamily=SANS)
   330â†’    ax.text(5.0, 0.6,
   331â†’            "No rejection sampling.  No branching.  No variable-length loops.",
   332â†’            fontsize=11, color=ACCENT_GREEN, ha="center", va="center",
   333â†’            fontfamily=SANS, style="italic")
   334â†’
   335â†’    # --- Red zone explanation ---
   336â†’    ax.text(5.0, 2.2,
   337â†’            "Remainders < 50 bits: too small to safely extract another coefficient",
   338â†’            fontsize=9, color=ACCENT_RED, ha="center", va="center",
   339â†’            fontfamily=SANS, style="italic", alpha=0.8)
   340â†’
   341â†’    out = OUTPUT_DIR / "day5_extraction_chain.png"
   342â†’    fig.savefig(out, dpi=DPI, bbox_inches="tight", pad_inches=0.15)
   343â†’    plt.close(fig)
   344â†’    print(f"  Saved {out}")
   345â†’
   346â†’
   347â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   348â†’# Image 3: Optimization waterfall
   349â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   350â†’
   351â†’def generate_optimization_waterfall():
   352â†’    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 7), dpi=DPI)
   353â†’    fig.patch.set_facecolor(BG)
   354â†’    ax.set_facecolor(BG)
   355â†’
   356â†’    # Data
   357â†’    labels = [
   358â†’        "Start",
   359â†’        "u16 \u2192 Zq\n(BoundedInt)",
   360â†’        "felt252\nalloc fix",
   361â†’        "BoundedInt\nnorm check",
   362â†’        "Fuse\nsub+norm",
   363â†’        "Fuse\ncompute",
   364â†’        "Fuse all +\nunroll K=8",
   365â†’    ]
   366â†’    values = [210_888, 189_102, 173_693, 154_776, 147_070, 143_463, 132_152]
   367â†’    deltas = [""] + [
   368â†’        f"-{(values[i-1] - values[i]) / values[i-1] * 100:.1f}%"
   369â†’        for i in range(1, len(values))
   370â†’    ]
   371â†’
   372â†’    n = len(values)
   373â†’    x = np.arange(n)
   374â†’
   375â†’    # Color gradient: red -> orange -> green
   376â†’    colors = []
   377â†’    for i in range(n):
   378â†’        t = i / (n - 1)
   379â†’        if t < 0.5:
   380â†’            # Red to orange
   381â†’            r = int(0xf7 + (0xff - 0xf7) * (t * 2))
   382â†’            g = int(0x76 + (0x9e - 0x76) * (t * 2))
   383â†’            b = int(0x8e + (0x64 - 0x8e) * (t * 2))
   384â†’        else:
   385â†’            # Orange to green
   386â†’            t2 = (t - 0.5) * 2
   387â†’            r = int(0xff + (0x9e - 0xff) * t2)
   388â†’            g = int(0x9e + (0xce - 0x9e) * t2)
   389â†’            b = int(0x64 + (0x6a - 0x64) * t2)
   390â†’        colors.append(f"#{r:02x}{g:02x}{b:02x}")
   391â†’
   392â†’    bars = ax.bar(x, values, width=0.65, color=colors, edgecolor="none",
   393â†’                  alpha=0.9, zorder=3)
   394â†’
   395â†’    # Value labels on top of each bar
   396â†’    for i, (val, delta) in enumerate(zip(values, deltas)):
   397â†’        ax.text(i, val + 3000, f"{val:,}",
   398â†’                ha="center", va="bottom", fontsize=11, fontweight="bold",
   399â†’                color=WHITE, fontfamily=MONO)
   400â†’        if delta:
   401â†’            ax.text(i, val + 9500, delta,
   402â†’                    ha="center", va="bottom", fontsize=9, fontweight="bold",
   403â†’                    color=colors[i], fontfamily=SANS)
   404â†’
   405â†’    # Day 1 target line at 230k
   406â†’    ax.axhline(y=230_000, color=ACCENT_ORANGE, linewidth=2,
   407â†’               linestyle="--", alpha=0.85, zorder=4)
   408â†’    ax.text(n - 0.5, 232_000, "Day 1 target: 230k",
   409â†’            fontsize=11, fontweight="bold", color=ACCENT_ORANGE,
   410â†’            ha="right", va="bottom", fontfamily=SANS)
   411â†’
   412â†’    # Final result annotation
   413â†’    ax.annotate(
   414â†’        f"-{(values[0] - values[-1]) / values[0] * 100:.0f}% total",
   415â†’        xy=(n - 1, values[-1]),
   416â†’        xytext=(n - 1 + 0.5, values[-1] + 30000),
   417â†’        fontsize=14, fontweight="bold", color=ACCENT_GREEN,
   418â†’        fontfamily=SANS,
   419â†’        arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->", color=ACCENT_GREEN, lw=2),
   420â†’        zorder=6,
   421â†’        bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", facecolor="#1a2d1a",
   422â†’                  edgecolor=ACCENT_GREEN, linewidth=1.2),
   423â†’    )
   424â†’
   425â†’    # X axis
   426â†’    ax.set_xticks(x)
   427â†’    ax.set_xticklabels(labels, fontsize=9, fontfamily=SANS, color=DIM_WHITE)
   428â†’
   429â†’    # Y axis
   430â†’    ax.set_ylim(0, 260_000)
   431â†’    ax.set_ylabel("Cairo VM Steps", fontsize=12, color=DIM_WHITE, fontfamily=SANS)
   432â†’
   433â†’    # Styling
   434â†’    ax.spines["top"].set_visible(False)
   435â†’    ax.spines["right"].set_visible(False)
   436â†’    ax.spines["bottom"].set_color(SEPARATOR)
   437â†’    ax.spines["left"].set_color(SEPARATOR)
   438â†’    ax.tick_params(axis="y", colors=COMMENT, labelsize=10)
   439â†’    ax.grid(axis="y", color=SEPARATOR, alpha=0.3, linewidth=0.5)
   440â†’
   441â†’    # Title
   442â†’    fig.text(0.5, 0.97, "Optimization Sprint: 210k \u2192 132k Steps",
   443â†’             fontsize=22, fontweight="bold", color=WHITE, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS)
   444â†’    fig.text(0.5, 0.93, "7 commits, one afternoon",
   445â†’             fontsize=13, color=COMMENT, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS, style="italic")
   446â†’
   447â†’    out = OUTPUT_DIR / "day5_optimization_waterfall.png"
   448â†’    fig.savefig(out, dpi=DPI, bbox_inches="tight", pad_inches=0.2)
   449â†’    plt.close(fig)
   450â†’    print(f"  Saved {out}")
   451â†’
   452â†’
   453â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   454â†’# Main
   455â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   456â†’
   457â†’def main():
   458â†’    _setup_style()
   459â†’    OUTPUT_DIR.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
   460â†’    print("Generating Day 5 thread visuals...")
   461â†’    generate_verify_flow()
   462â†’    generate_extraction_chain()
   463â†’    generate_optimization_waterfall()
   464â†’    print("Done!")
   465â†’
   466â†’
   467â†’if __name__ == "__main__":
   468â†’    main()
   469â†’

1â†’"""
     2â†’Hash-to-Point cost optimization for Falcon on Starknet.
     3â†’
     4â†’Models the tradeoff between bits-per-coefficient and total cost
     5â†’for rejection-sampling coefficients mod q=12289 from hash output.
     6â†’
     7â†’Produces three plots:
     8â†’  1. Total cost vs bits-per-coefficient (Poseidon & Blake2s)
     9â†’  2. Hash calls vs bits-per-coefficient
    10â†’  3. Sensitivity: optimal b as hash_cost varies
    11â†’
    12â†’Usage:
    13â†’    python scripts/hash_tradeoff.py
    14â†’"""
    15â†’
    16â†’from __future__ import annotations
    17â†’
    18â†’import math
    19â†’from pathlib import Path
    20â†’
    21â†’import matplotlib
    22â†’matplotlib.use("Agg")
    23â†’
    24â†’import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
    25â†’import numpy as np
    26â†’
    27â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    28â†’# Tokyo Night palette (shared with thread_visuals.py)
    29â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    30â†’BG = "#1a1b26"
    31â†’BG_PANEL = "#24283b"
    32â†’FG = "#c0caf5"
    33â†’COMMENT = "#565f89"
    34â†’KEYWORD = "#bb9af7"      # purple
    35â†’TYPE = "#7dcfff"          # cyan
    36â†’NUMBER = "#ff9e64"        # orange
    37â†’STRING = "#9ece6a"        # green
    38â†’ACCENT_GREEN = "#9ece6a"
    39â†’ACCENT_CYAN = "#7dcfff"
    40â†’ACCENT_RED = "#f7768e"
    41â†’ACCENT_ORANGE = "#ff9e64"
    42â†’WHITE = "#ffffff"
    43â†’DIM_WHITE = "#a9b1d6"
    44â†’SEPARATOR = "#3b4261"
    45â†’
    46â†’SANS = "DejaVu Sans"
    47â†’MONO = "DejaVu Sans Mono"
    48â†’
    49â†’OUTPUT_DIR = Path(__file__).resolve().parent / "thread_output"
    50â†’DPI = 200
    51â†’
    52â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    53â†’# Parameters
    54â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    55â†’Q = 12289
    56â†’N_COEFFS = 512
    57â†’
    58â†’# Hash configurations
    59â†’CONFIGS = {
    60â†’    "Poseidon": {
    61â†’        "hash_bits": 251,    # usable bits per felt252 element
    62â†’        "hash_rate": 2,      # elements absorbed per permutation
    63â†’        "hash_cost": 500,    # steps per hash call (estimate)
    64â†’        "color": ACCENT_CYAN,
    65â†’        "linestyle": "-",
    66â†’    },
    67â†’    "Blake2s": {
    68â†’        "hash_bits": 256,    # bits per output
    69â†’        "hash_rate": 1,      # one 256-bit output per call
    70â†’        "hash_cost": 2000,   # steps per call (native opcode estimate)
    71â†’        "color": ACCENT_ORANGE,
    72â†’        "linestyle": "--",
    73â†’    },
    74â†’}
    75â†’
    76â†’SPLIT_COST = 20    # steps per chunk extraction (felt252 division)
    77â†’REDUCE_COST = 50   # steps per mod q (bounded_int_div_rem)
    78â†’
    79â†’
    80â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    81â†’# Core model
    82â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    83â†’
    84â†’def acceptance_rate(b: int) -> float:
    85â†’    """Fraction of b-bit samples that fall in [0, floor(2^b/q)*q)."""
    86â†’    b = int(b)  # ensure Python int for arbitrary precision
    87â†’    two_b = 2**b
    88â†’    return (two_b // Q) * Q / two_b
    89â†’
    90â†’
    91â†’def renyi_security_loss_bits(b: int) -> float:
    92â†’    """Approximate RÃ©nyi divergence security loss in bits.
    93â†’
    94â†’    From the Falcon spec analysis: for 2^73 queries,
    95â†’    loss â‰ˆ 2^73 * q^2 / (4 * 2^(2b) * ln(2))
    96â†’
    97â†’    Computed in log-space to avoid overflow for large b.
    98â†’    """
    99â†’    # log2(loss) = 73 + 2*log2(q) - 2*b - 2 - log2(ln(2))
   100â†’    log2_loss = 73 + 2 * math.log2(Q) - 2 * b - 2 - math.log2(math.log(2))
   101â†’    if log2_loss < -1074:  # below float64 subnormal
   102â†’        return 0.0
   103â†’    return 2**log2_loss
   104â†’
   105â†’
   106â†’def compute_cost(b: int, hash_bits: int, hash_rate: int,
   107â†’                 hash_cost: float, split_cost: float = SPLIT_COST,
   108â†’                 reduce_cost: float = REDUCE_COST) -> dict:
   109â†’    """Compute expected cost for a given bits-per-coefficient."""
   110â†’    b = int(b)  # ensure Python int
   111â†’    coeffs_per_element = hash_bits // b
   112â†’    coeffs_per_hash = coeffs_per_element * hash_rate
   113â†’
   114â†’    if coeffs_per_hash == 0:
   115â†’        return {"total": float("inf"), "hash_calls": float("inf"),
   116â†’                "raw_samples": float("inf"), "acceptance": 0.0}
   117â†’
   118â†’    acc = acceptance_rate(b)
   119â†’    raw_samples = N_COEFFS / acc if acc > 0 else float("inf")
   120â†’    hash_calls = math.ceil(raw_samples / coeffs_per_hash)
   121â†’
   122â†’    total = (hash_calls * hash_cost
   123â†’             + N_COEFFS * reduce_cost
   124â†’             + raw_samples * split_cost)
   125â†’
   126â†’    return {
   127â†’        "total": total,
   128â†’        "hash_calls": hash_calls,
   129â†’        "raw_samples": raw_samples,
   130â†’        "acceptance": acc,
   131â†’    }
   132â†’
   133â†’
   134â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   135â†’# Style setup
   136â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   137â†’
   138â†’def _setup_style():
   139â†’    plt.style.use("dark_background")
   140â†’    plt.rcParams.update({
   141â†’        "figure.facecolor": BG,
   142â†’        "axes.facecolor": BG_PANEL,
   143â†’        "savefig.facecolor": BG,
   144â†’        "text.color": FG,
   145â†’        "font.family": "sans-serif",
   146â†’        "font.sans-serif": [SANS],
   147â†’        "axes.edgecolor": SEPARATOR,
   148â†’        "axes.labelcolor": DIM_WHITE,
   149â†’        "xtick.color": COMMENT,
   150â†’        "ytick.color": COMMENT,
   151â†’        "grid.color": SEPARATOR,
   152â†’        "grid.alpha": 0.4,
   153â†’    })
   154â†’
   155â†’
   156â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   157â†’# Plot 1: Total cost vs bits-per-coefficient
   158â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   159â†’
   160â†’def plot_total_cost():
   161â†’    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 6.5), dpi=DPI)
   162â†’
   163â†’    b_range = np.arange(14, 129)

   165â†’    # RÃ©nyi security boundary
   166â†’    security_boundary = None

   168â†’        if renyi_security_loss_bits(b) < 1.0:
   169â†’            security_boundary = b
   170â†’            break
   171â†’
   172â†’    # Shade insecure zone
   173â†’    if security_boundary is not None:
   174â†’        ax.axvspan(14, security_boundary, color=ACCENT_RED, alpha=0.08,
   175â†’                   zorder=0, label=f"RÃ©nyi loss > 1 bit (b < {security_boundary})")
   176â†’        ax.axvline(security_boundary, color=ACCENT_RED, linewidth=1,
   177â†’                   linestyle=":", alpha=0.6)
   178â†’        ax.text(security_boundary - 1, ax.get_ylim()[1] if ax.get_ylim()[1] > 0 else 1e6,
   179â†’                f"b={security_boundary}", fontsize=9, color=ACCENT_RED,
   180â†’                ha="right", va="top", fontfamily=SANS)
   181â†’
   182â†’    best = {}
