   185â†’        for b in b_range:
   186â†’            r = compute_cost(b, cfg["hash_bits"], cfg["hash_rate"], cfg["hash_cost"])
   187â†’            costs.append(r["total"])
   188â†’
   189â†’        costs = np.array(costs)
   190â†’        ax.plot(b_range, costs, color=cfg["color"], linewidth=2.5,
   191â†’                linestyle=cfg["linestyle"], label=name, zorder=5)
   192â†’
   193â†’        # Find optimal
   194â†’        valid_mask = np.array([renyi_security_loss_bits(int(b)) < 1.0 for b in b_range])
   195â†’        safe_costs = np.where(valid_mask, costs, np.inf)
   196â†’        opt_idx = np.argmin(safe_costs)
   197â†’        opt_b = int(b_range[opt_idx])
   198â†’        opt_cost = costs[opt_idx]
   199â†’        best[name] = (opt_b, opt_cost)
   200â†’
   201â†’        ax.plot(opt_b, opt_cost, "o", color=cfg["color"], markersize=10,
   202â†’                zorder=6, markeredgecolor=WHITE, markeredgewidth=1.5)
   203â†’        ax.annotate(f"optimal b={opt_b}\n{opt_cost:,.0f} steps",
   204â†’                    xy=(opt_b, opt_cost),
   205â†’                    xytext=(opt_b + 8, opt_cost * 1.15),
   206â†’                    fontsize=10, fontweight="bold", color=cfg["color"],
   207â†’                    fontfamily=SANS,
   208â†’                    arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->", color=cfg["color"], lw=1.5),
   209â†’                    zorder=7)
   210â†’
   211â†’    # Re-shade after data is plotted (so ylim is set)
   212â†’    if security_boundary is not None:
   213â†’        ax.axvspan(14, security_boundary, color=ACCENT_RED, alpha=0.08, zorder=0)
   214â†’        ax.text(security_boundary - 1, ax.get_ylim()[1] * 0.95,
   215â†’                f"b<{security_boundary}: insecure", fontsize=9, color=ACCENT_RED,
   216â†’                ha="right", va="top", fontfamily=SANS, fontstyle="italic")
   217â†’
   218â†’    # Vertical markers at notable b values
   219â†’    ylo, yhi = ax.get_ylim()
   220â†’    marker_defs = [
   221â†’        (16, "b=16 (spec)", 0.55),
   222â†’        (64, "b=64 (Falcon var.)", 0.65),
   223â†’        (83, "b=83 (âŒŠ251/3âŒ‹)", 0.55),
   224â†’    ]
   225â†’    for b_val, label, y_frac in marker_defs:
   226â†’        if 14 <= b_val <= 128:

   228â†’            ax.text(b_val + 1, ylo + (yhi - ylo) * y_frac, label,

   232â†’    ax.set_xlabel("Bits per coefficient (b)", fontsize=12, fontfamily=SANS)
   233â†’    ax.set_ylabel("Total cost (Cairo steps)", fontsize=12, fontfamily=SANS)
   234â†’    ax.set_title("Hash-to-Point Cost: Poseidon vs Blake2s",
   235â†’                 fontsize=18, fontweight="bold", color=WHITE, fontfamily=SANS, pad=15)
   236â†’    ax.legend(fontsize=11, loc="upper right", framealpha=0.8,
   237â†’              edgecolor=SEPARATOR, facecolor=BG_PANEL)
   238â†’    ax.grid(True, linewidth=0.5)
   239â†’    ax.set_xlim(14, 128)
   240â†’
   241â†’    out = OUTPUT_DIR / "hash_tradeoff_cost.png"
   242â†’    fig.savefig(out, dpi=DPI, bbox_inches="tight", pad_inches=0.2)
   243â†’    plt.close(fig)
   244â†’    print(f"  Saved {out}")
   245â†’    return best

   259â†’        calls_reject = []

   261â†’        calls_no_reject = []

   306â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

   308â†’# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

data.prompt:
Thoroughly explore the /home/felt/PycharmProjects/s2morrow/scripts/thread/ directory. I need to understand:

1. All files and their purposes (list everything recursively)
2. The .env file structure (what keys are needed, don't show values)
3. All CLI commands in thread.py (context, sessions, push, list, fetch, gold)
4. The thread markdown format with all supported directives (# title, reply_to:, ## Post N, ---, > ATTACH:)

content.content:
1â†’# Day 5 Thread
     2â†’reply_to: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2021250459210743914
     3â†’
     4â†’## Post 1
     5â†’[DAY 5] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet. I built the full Falcon-512 verification in one afternoon â€” types, hash function, signature checking, cross-language tests. Then spent the next afternoon cutting it by 37%.
     6â†’
     7â†’132k Cairo steps. The 230k target from Day 1 is beaten.
     8â†’
     9â†’---
    10â†’
    11â†’## Post 2
    12â†’The hash function was the interesting design problem. Falcon needs to hash a message into 512 coefficients mod 12289. The spec uses SHAKE256 with rejection sampling: extract 16 bits, reject if biased, retry. That's branching and variable-length loops, expensive in a ZK VM.
    13â†’
    14â†’Blake2s would be ideal â€” native opcode, 2-3x cheaper than Poseidon â€” but I asked @Starkware and it won't be available to contracts until 0.14.2 in April. Poseidon it is.
    15â†’
    16â†’---
    17â†’
    18â†’## Post 3
    19â†’I looked at how @0xMiden does their Falcon with Poseidon2. They skip rejection entirely and extract more bits per coefficient instead. The trick is in the Falcon spec itself (page 31): if your hash output is much larger than q, the modular bias becomes negligible.
    20â†’
    21â†’With 16-bit inputs some residues get 25% more pre-images than others. With 128-bit inputs the bias is parts per 10^38. A Renyi divergence argument makes it formal. Minimum safe is ~50 bits; we extract from 128. Overkill.
    22â†’
    23â†’---
    24â†’
    25â†’## Post 4
    26â†’So I built base-Q extraction chains. Each Poseidon output is a felt252 â€” 251 bits. Split into a low u128 and a high 124-bit part, then extract coefficients with repeated DivRem-by-q: divide, take remainder, repeat. 6 from each half. 12 coefficients per felt252.
    27â†’
    28â†’22 Poseidon permutations for all 512 coefficients. No rejection, no branching, no variable-length loops.
    29â†’
    30â†’> ATTACH: day5_extraction_chain.png
    31â†’
    32â†’---
    33â†’
    34â†’## Post 5
    35â†’The BoundedInt type chains for this are painful though. Each DivRem step needs exact quotient and remainder types. Two separate chains because u128 and FeltHigh have different upper bounds. 40+ type definitions just for the extraction logic.
    36â†’
    37â†’But the compiler uses those bounds to skip every overflow check. Without BoundedInt each division needs a u256 intermediate and a try_into cast back down â€” doubling the cost. Same lesson from Day 2: the pain pays for itself.
    38â†’
    39â†’---
    40â†’
    41â†’## Post 6
    42â†’I also moved the INTT off-chain. Standard Falcon: NTT the signature, multiply by public key, INTT back, check norm. Three transforms. Instead, the signer computes mul_hint = INTT(NTT(s1) * pk_ntt) and sends it alongside the signature. The verifier just re-checks the forward direction: NTT(mul_hint) == NTT(s1) * pk_ntt.
    43â†’
    44â†’Two NTTs, zero INTTs.
    45â†’
    46â†’> ATTACH: day5_verify_flow.png
    47â†’
    48â†’---
    49â†’
    50â†’## Post 7
    51â†’Then I found a free optimization. I originally wrote a custom absorb function for the Poseidon sponge â€” rate-2 absorption, padding, domain separation, the whole thing. Then I realized Cairo's built-in poseidon_hash_span does the exact same thing. Replaced 20 lines with one function call. 33% gas reduction on hash_to_point.
    52â†’
    53â†’---
    54â†’
    55â†’## Post 8
    56â†’The next day I went on an optimization sprint. 7 commits in one afternoon.
    57â†’
    58â†’The verification had three separate 512-element loops: multiply and check the hint, subtract to get s0, compute both norms. I fused them into a single pass. Then unrolled with multi_pop_front K=8. 210k to 132k steps.
    59â†’
    60â†’> ATTACH: day5_optimization_waterfall.png
    61â†’
    62â†’---
    63â†’
    64â†’## Post 9
    65â†’I also built a companion Rust crate (falcon-rs) with a generic hash trait â€” swap SHAKE256 for Poseidon. It passes NIST's 100 known-answer test vectors for standard Falcon. Same keygen and signing; only the hash changes.
    66â†’
    67â†’Rust generates all the Cairo test data. Cairo deserializes and checks element-by-element. 27 Cairo tests, 61 Rust tests. https://github.com/feltroidprime/falcon-rs
    68â†’
    69â†’---
    70â†’
    71â†’## Post 10
    72â†’132k steps, down from 800k on Day 1. -83.5%.
    73â†’
    74â†’Next: wiring this into an actual account contract. __validate__ calls verify, public key in storage packed into 29 felt252 slots, signature + hint in calldata. When Blake2s ships in 0.14.2, @zknoxhq's hash-to-point drops in and we move toward spec-compliant Falcon on a live network. Let's see.
    75â†’

### 2. Environment File (.env) Structure

**Location:** `/home/felt/PycharmProjects/s2morrow/scripts/thread/.env`

**Required keys (from .env.example):**
```
TYPEFULLY_API_KEY=<api_key_value>
TYPEFULLY_SOCIAL_SET_ID=<social_set_id_value>
```

**Purpose:** Credentials for Typefully API integration (push drafts, list, fetch published threads).

### 3. All CLI Commands in thread.py

The script uses argparse with 6 subcommands:

#### **Command 1: context**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py context --since 2026-02-11 [--until 2026-02-13]
```
- **Gathers context for a new thread** from multiple sources
- Outputs to `context_output.md`
- Sources:
  1. Git log (commits, file changes in date range)
  2. Claude Code sessions (JSONL files from `~/.claude/projects/`)
  3. Profile images (from `profiles/` directory if exists)
  4. Gold moments (from `gold_moments.md`)
- **Default until:** 2 days after `--since`

#### **Command 2: sessions**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py sessions --since 2026-02-11 [--until DATE]
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py sessions --id UUID_PREFIX [--output FILE]
```
- **List Claude Code sessions** by date range (sorted by size, largest first)
- **Read a specific session** by UUID prefix: extracts human-readable conversation (USER/ASSISTANT blocks)
- Displays: size, timestamp, tool count, first prompt preview
- Optional `--output` flag to write to file instead of stdout

#### **Command 3: push**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py push scripts/thread/threads/day5/thread.md [--update DRAFT_ID] [--dry-run]
```
- **Push a thread markdown file to Typefully as a draft**
- Parses markdown (see markdown format below)
- Uploads media attachments (images/videos)
- Auto-detects draft ID from `.typefully_state.json` if exists
- `--update` flag updates an existing draft instead of creating new
- `--dry-run` previews without sending
- Saves state to `thread.md.typefully_state.json` with draft_id and private_url

#### **Command 4: list**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py list
```
- **List all Typefully drafts** for the configured social set
- Shows: draft_id, status, title, private_url

#### **Command 5: fetch**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py fetch
```
- **Fetch published threads from Typefully** and save locally
- Downloads all media (images/videos)
- Creates per-thread markdown files:
  - `threads/dayN/published.md` (if day detected in first post)
  - `threads/dayN/media/` (downloaded media files)
- Creates combined `published_threads.md` (all threads in LLM-ready format)
- Detects [DAY N] pattern in first post

#### **Command 6: gold**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py gold "moment description" [--day 5]
```
- **Add a gold moment** to `gold_moments.md` with timestamp
- Auto-detects day from `context.md` if omitted
- Creates `## Day N` section if needed
- Appends chronologically within day sections

### 4. Thread Markdown Format with All Supported Directives

**File location:** `threads/dayN/thread.md`

**Directives (all case-sensitive):**

```markdown
# Title of the thread
reply_to: https://x.com/user/status/12345

## Post 1
Post content can be multiple lines.
Multiple paragraphs work fine.

Any markdown formatting is preserved: **bold**, *italic*, links, etc.

---

## Post 2
> ATTACH: image_name.png

> ATTACH: `another_image.png`

Post text continues here.

---

## Post 3
Text without attachments.
```

**Parsing rules:**
- `# ` (line start) â†’ title (first occurrence only)
- `reply_to:` (case-insensitive prefix) â†’ URL to quote (sets reply-to-url in Typefully)
- `## Post N` â†’ post separator (N is any digit sequence)
- `---` (horizontal rule) â†’ ignored (visual separator, optional)
- `> ATTACH: filename` or `> ATTACH: \`filename\`` â†’ attachment path
  - Resolved in order: relative to thread_dir, then `visuals/dayN_output/`, then `visuals/thread_output/`
- Text between posts â†’ post body

**Example complete structure:**
```markdown
# Day 5: Full Verification Pipeline
reply_to: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2021250459210743914

## Post 1
[DAY 5] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet. I built the full Falcon-512 verification in one afternoon.

132k Cairo steps. The 230k target from Day 1 is beaten.

---

## Post 2
The hash function was interesting.

> ATTACH: day5_extraction_chain.png

---

## Post 3
Final content.
```

### 5. Visuals Scripts: Palettes, Patterns, Output Directories

#### **thread_visuals.py** (Day 4 NTT Comparison)

**Output directory:** `visuals/thread_output/` (or `images/` symlink)

**Palette (Tokyo Night theme):**
```python
BG = "#1a1b26"              # Dark background
BG_PANEL = "#24283b"        # Panel background
FG = "#c0caf5"              # Foreground text
ACCENT_GREEN = "#9ece6a"    # Our approach (green)
ACCENT_RED = "#f7768e"      # zknox approach (red)
ACCENT_ORANGE = "#ff9e64"   # Orange highlights
ACCENT_CYAN = "#7dcfff"     # Cyan accents
KEYWORD = "#bb9af7"         # Purple
COMMENT = "#565f89"         # Gray comments
```

**Generates 3 PNG images:**
1. **ntt_comparison_code.png** â€” Side-by-side syntax-highlighted code
   - Left: zknox approach (shift every butterfly, u256 reduce)
   - Right: Our approach (allow negatives, u128 reduce)
   - Syntax coloring for Cairo-like code

2. **ntt_comparison_bars.png** â€” Horizontal bar chart
   - zknox: 63,479 steps
   - Ours: 15,353 steps
   - Shows 4.1x speedup
   - References secp256r1 baseline (230k)

3. **ntt_shift_diagram.png** â€” Architecture flow diagram
   - Top row: zknox (shift after each butterfly, then u256)
   - Bottom row: Ours (plain butterflies, one shift, u128 reduce)
   - Flow boxes with arrows
   - Highlights key insight

#### **day5_visuals.py** (Day 5 Verification Pipeline)

**Output directory:** `visuals/day5_output/`

**Same palette as thread_visuals.py**

**Generates 3 PNG images:**
1. **day5_verify_flow.png** â€” Standard vs Hint-based verification
   - Top: Standard (NTT â†’ Multiply â†’ INTT â†’ Norm)
   - Bottom: Hint-based (NTT â†’ Multiply â†’ NTT(hint) â†’ Compare â†’ Norm)
   - Shows "2 NTTs, 0 INTTs" optimization

2. **day5_extraction_chain.png** â€” Base-Q DivRem extraction
   - felt252 (251 bits) â†’ split â†’ u128 + FeltHigh
   - 6 DivRem steps per branch
   - 12 coefficients per felt252
   - Summary: 22 Poseidon permutations = 512+ coefficients

3. **day5_optimization_waterfall.png** â€” Step count waterfall
   - X-axis: optimization stages
   - Values: 210,888 â†’ 189,102 â†’ 173,693 â†’ ... â†’ 132,152
   - Shows -37% total reduction
   - Marks Day 1 target (230k) with dashed line

#### **hash_tradeoff.py** (Hash-to-Point Cost Modeling)

**Output directory:** `images/` (shared with thread_visuals output)

**Palette:** Same Tokyo Night theme

**Generates 3 PNG images:**
1. **hash_tradeoff_cost.png** â€” Total cost vs bits-per-coefficient
   - Poseidon vs Blake2s curves
   - Shows optimal b value for each
   - RÃ©nyi security boundary shaded
   - References notable b values (16, 64, 83)

2. **hash_tradeoff_calls.png** â€” Hash calls vs extraction width
   - With rejection vs without rejection
   - Shows acceptance rate improvement

3. **hash_tradeoff_sensitivity.png** â€” Cost breakdown (stacked areas)
   - Two subplots: Poseidon and Blake2s
   - Components: hash calls, split/extract, mod-q reduce
   - Marks optimal b with dot annotation

**Model parameters:**
- Q = 12289 (Falcon modulus)
- N_COEFFS = 512 (signature size)
- Poseidon: 251 bits, rate=2, cost=500 steps/call
- Blake2s: 256 bits, rate=1, cost=2000 steps/call
- split_cost = 20 steps per chunk extraction
- reduce_cost = 50 steps per DivRem

- Casual technical, short/long sentence mix

- Show work, don't narrate
- Low-key endings ("Let's see" not "LET'S GOOO")
- Never use: "Plot twist:", "ðŸ§µ", "Thread:", "Here's the thing...", etc.

## Writing Rules (Strunk)
- Write actual sentences (subject + verb)
- No comma splices
- Active voice
- Positive form
- Specific and concrete
- Omit needless words
- Emphatic words at end
- Tell stories, don't list facts

TYPEFULLY_SOCIAL_SET_ID=<social_set_id_value>
```

**Purpose:** Credentials for Typefully API integration (push drafts, list, fetch published threads).

### 3. All CLI Commands in thread.py

The script uses argparse with 6 subcommands:

#### **Command 1: context**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py context --since 2026-02-11 [--until 2026-02-13]
```
- **Gathers context for a new thread** from multiple sources
- Outputs to `context_output.md`
- Sources:
  1. Git log (commits, file changes in date range)
  2. Claude Code sessions (JSONL files from `~/.claude/projects/`)
  3. Profile images (from `profiles/` directory if exists)
  4. Gold moments (from `gold_moments.md`)
- **Default until:** 2 days after `--since`

#### **Command 2: sessions**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py sessions --since 2026-02-11 [--until DATE]
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py sessions --id UUID_PREFIX [--output FILE]
```
- **List Claude Code sessions** by date range (sorted by size, largest first)
- **Read a specific session** by UUID prefix: extracts human-readable conversation (USER/ASSISTANT blocks)
- Displays: size, timestamp, tool count, first prompt preview
- Optional `--output` flag to write to file instead of stdout

#### **Command 3: push**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py push scripts/thread/threads/day5/thread.md [--update DRAFT_ID] [--dry-run]
```
- **Push a thread markdown file to Typefully as a draft**
- Parses markdown (see markdown format below)
- Uploads media attachments (images/videos)
- Auto-detects draft ID from `.typefully_state.json` if exists
- `--update` flag updates an existing draft instead of creating new
- `--dry-run` previews without sending
- Saves state to `thread.md.typefully_state.json` with draft_id and private_url

#### **Command 4: list**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py list
```
- **List all Typefully drafts** for the configured social set
- Shows: draft_id, status, title, private_url

#### **Command 5: fetch**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py fetch
```
- **Fetch published threads from Typefully** and save locally
- Downloads all media (images/videos)
- Creates per-thread markdown files:
  - `threads/dayN/published.md` (if day detected in first post)
  - `threads/dayN/media/` (downloaded media files)
- Creates combined `published_threads.md` (all threads in LLM-ready format)
- Detects [DAY N] pattern in first post

#### **Command 6: gold**
```bash
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py gold "moment description" [--day 5]
```
- **Add a gold moment** to `gold_moments.md` with timestamp
- Auto-detects day from `context.md` if omitted
- Creates `## Day N` section if needed
- Appends chronologically within day sections

### 4. Thread Markdown Format with All Supported Directives

**File location:** `threads/dayN/thread.md`

**Directives (all case-sensitive):**

```markdown
# Title of the thread
reply_to: https://x.com/user/status/12345

## Post 1
Post content can be multiple lines.
Multiple paragraphs work fine.

Any markdown formatting is preserved: **bold**, *italic*, links, etc.

---

## Post 2
> ATTACH: image_name.png

> ATTACH: `another_image.png`

Post text continues here.

---

## Post 3
Text without attachments.
```

**Parsing rules:**
- `# ` (line start) â†’ title (first occurrence only)
- `reply_to:` (case-insensitive prefix) â†’ URL to quote (sets reply-to-url in Typefully)
- `## Post N` â†’ post separator (N is any digit sequence)
- `---` (horizontal rule) â†’ ignored (visual separator, optional)
- `> ATTACH: filename` or `> ATTACH: \`filename\`` â†’ attachment path
  - Resolved in order: relative to thread_dir, then `visuals/dayN_output/`, then `visuals/thread_output/`
- Text between posts â†’ post body

**Example complete structure:**
```markdown
# Day 5: Full Verification Pipeline
reply_to: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2021250459210743914

## Post 1
[DAY 5] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet. I built the full Falcon-512 verification in one afternoon.

132k Cairo steps. The 230k target from Day 1 is beaten.

---

## Post 2
The hash function was interesting.

> ATTACH: day5_extraction_chain.png

---

## Post 3
Final content.
```

### 5. Visuals Scripts: Palettes, Patterns, Output Directories

#### **thread_visuals.py** (Day 4 NTT Comparison)

**Output directory:** `visuals/thread_output/` (or `images/` symlink)

**Palette (Tokyo Night theme):**
```python
BG = "#1a1b26"              # Dark background
BG_PANEL = "#24283b"        # Panel background
FG = "#c0caf5"              # Foreground text
ACCENT_GREEN = "#9ece6a"    # Our approach (green)
ACCENT_RED = "#f7768e"      # zknox approach (red)
ACCENT_ORANGE = "#ff9e64"   # Orange highlights
ACCENT_CYAN = "#7dcfff"     # Cyan accents
KEYWORD = "#bb9af7"         # Purple
COMMENT = "#565f89"         # Gray comments
```

**Generates 3 PNG images:**
1. **ntt_comparison_code.png** â€” Side-by-side syntax-highlighted code
   - Left: zknox approach (shift every butterfly, u256 reduce)
   - Right: Our approach (allow negatives, u128 reduce)
   - Syntax coloring for Cairo-like code

2. **ntt_comparison_bars.png** â€” Horizontal bar chart
   - zknox: 63,479 steps
   - Ours: 15,353 steps
   - Shows 4.1x speedup
   - References secp256r1 baseline (230k)

3. **ntt_shift_diagram.png** â€” Architecture flow diagram
   - Top row: zknox (shift after each butterfly, then u256)
   - Bottom row: Ours (plain butterflies, one shift, u128 reduce)
   - Flow boxes with arrows
   - Highlights key insight

#### **day5_visuals.py** (Day 5 Verification Pipeline)

**Output directory:** `visuals/day5_output/`

**Same palette as thread_visuals.py**

**Generates 3 PNG images:**
1. **day5_verify_flow.png** â€” Standard vs Hint-based verification
   - Top: Standard (NTT â†’ Multiply â†’ INTT â†’ Norm)
   - Bottom: Hint-based (NTT â†’ Multiply â†’ NTT(hint) â†’ Compare â†’ Norm)
   - Shows "2 NTTs, 0 INTTs" optimization

2. **day5_extraction_chain.png** â€” Base-Q DivRem extraction
   - felt252 (251 bits) â†’ split â†’ u128 + FeltHigh
   - 6 DivRem steps per branch
   - 12 coefficients per felt252
   - Summary: 22 Poseidon permutations = 512+ coefficients

3. **day5_optimization_waterfall.png** â€” Step count waterfall
   - X-axis: optimization stages
   - Values: 210,888 â†’ 189,102 â†’ 173,693 â†’ ... â†’ 132,152
   - Shows -37% total reduction
   - Marks Day 1 target (230k) with dashed line

#### **hash_tradeoff.py** (Hash-to-Point Cost Modeling)

**Output directory:** `images/` (shared with thread_visuals output)

**Palette:** Same Tokyo Night theme

**Generates 3 PNG images:**
1. **hash_tradeoff_cost.png** â€” Total cost vs bits-per-coefficient
   - Poseidon vs Blake2s curves
   - Shows optimal b value for each
   - RÃ©nyi security boundary shaded
   - References notable b values (16, 64, 83)

2. **hash_tradeoff_calls.png** â€” Hash calls vs extraction width
   - With rejection vs without rejection
   - Shows acceptance rate improvement

3. **hash_tradeoff_sensitivity.png** â€” Cost breakdown (stacked areas)
   - Two subplots: Poseidon and Blake2s
   - Components: hash calls, split/extract, mod-q reduce
   - Marks optimal b with dot annotation

**Model parameters:**
- Q = 12289 (Falcon modulus)
- N_COEFFS = 512 (signature size)
- Poseidon: 251 bits, rate=2, cost=500 steps/call
- Blake2s: 256 bits, rate=1, cost=2000 steps/call
- split_cost = 20 steps per chunk extraction
- reduce_cost = 50 steps per DivRem

### 6. Threads Subdirectory Structure (day1-5)

Each `dayN/` contains:

```
dayN/
â”œâ”€â”€ published.md          # Downloaded from Typefully (if published)
â”œâ”€â”€ thread.md             # Draft markdown (push-ready)
â”œâ”€â”€ skeleton.md           # Raw skeleton/brainstorm (optional)
â”œâ”€â”€ thread.typefully_state.json  # Tracks draft_id, private_url (if pushed)
â””â”€â”€ media/
    â””â”€â”€ postM_XXXXXXXX.{png|mp4}  # Downloaded post attachments
```

**Per-day snapshot:**
- **day1:** 3 posts published, 3 media files in `media/`
- **day2:** 11 posts published, 3 media files
- **day3:** 9 posts published, 5 media files (1 MP4 video)
- **day4:** 11 posts published, 3 media files + `thread.md` (draft)
- **day5:** `thread.md` (draft with 10 posts), `skeleton.md`, `typefully_state.json` (pushed), no media yet

**Root threads/media/:** 2 image files (old global media directory, mostly superseded by dayN/media/)

**Special files:**
- `published_5651214.md` â€” Older published thread (not day-numbered)

### 7. Gitignore Patterns for This Directory

The `.entire/.gitignore` file (cache directory) likely contains:
```
*.log
*.json
```

**Recommended patterns for scripts/thread/ root .gitignore (if any):**
- `.env` (API credentials)
- `__pycache__/`
- `.entire/` (internal cache)
- `context_output.md` (generated temporary)

### 8. Key Files: published_threads.md and gold_moments.md

#### **published_threads.md** (12.8 KB)
- **Generated by `fetch` command**
- Combined archive of all published threads
- Format: LLM-ready markdown with inline media references
- Structure:
  ```markdown
  # Published Threads
  
  ## Day 1 â€” Published 2026-01-27
  url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/...
  
  1/9
  [DAY 1] Quantum computers...
  ![](threads/day1/media/...)
  
  2/9
  ...
  
  ---
  
  ## Day 2 â€” Published 2026-01-28
  ...
  ```
- Contains all 4 days + 1 legacy thread
- Media paths are relative to `threads/dayN/`

#### **gold_moments.md** (1.5 KB)
- **Running log of notable breakthroughs**
- Manually appended via `gold` command or edited directly
- Structure:
  ```markdown
  # Gold Moments
  
  ## Day 5 (Feb 11-12)
  
  ### Breakthroughs
  - Built full Falcon verification...
  - Hash-to-point: 12 coefficients per felt252...
  - [timestamp] Optimization sprint...
  
  ### Pain points
  - BoundedInt type chains: 40+ definitions...
  
  ### Key numbers
  - Verify e2e: 210,888 â†’ ... â†’ 132,152 steps
  - Total reduction from Day 1: 800k â†’ 132k (-83.5%)
  
  ### Claude sessions (Feb 11-12)
  - 93b550ca (26.9 MB, Feb 11 15:11) â€” Full prod-ready implementation
  ```
- Used by `context` command to include in new thread context

### 9. context.md File (Global Context Store)

**Location:** `/home/felt/PycharmProjects/s2morrow/scripts/thread/context.md` (7.3 KB)

**Structure:**
```markdown
# Thread Context â€” Quantum Wallet Build-in-Public

## System
- Project info, CLI commands, context sources

## What This Is
- Description of the build-in-public series (Falcon-512 post-quantum wallet on Starknet)
- "Day" means "episode," not calendar day

## Voice
- Casual technical, short/long sentence mix
- Confidence without performance
- Show work, don't narrate
- Low-key endings ("Let's see" not "LET'S GOOO")
- Never use: "Plot twist:", "ðŸ§µ", "Thread:", "Here's the thing...", etc.

## Writing Rules (Strunk)
- Write actual sentences (subject + verb)
- No comma splices
- Active voice
- Positive form
- Specific and concrete
- Omit needless words
- Emphatic words at end
- Tell stories, don't list facts

## Audiences
- Cairo/Starknet builders (core, technical depth OK)
- Crypto speculators (want stakes, need anchors)
- Ethereum/quantum researchers (know PQ crypto, need credibility)

## Thread Structure
1. Hook â€” create tension
2. Work â€” what I did with code/screenshots/numbers
3. Obstacle or insight
4. Results â€” concrete numbers
5. Closer â€” tease what's next

## Running Narratives
- Performance target (230k from Day 1)
- The compiler (BoundedInt circuit compiler)
- BoundedInt arc (Day 2-4 correction to hybrid mode)
- zknox collaboration (complementary Falcon NTT work)
- 230k budget breakdown

## Previous Threads Summary
- Day 1: Hook on quantum threat, benchmarked to 230k target
- Day 2: 65% overhead, BoundedInt optimization
- Day 3: Built circuit compiler, 5x NTT speedup
- Day 4: zknox comparison, shift strategy, hybrid mode
```

---

## Summary Statistics

- **Total Python files:** 4 (thread.py + 3 visuals scripts)
- **Total markdown files:** ~20 (README, context, gold_moments, research, published threads, drafts)
- **Total PNG/media files:** 15 (6 in images/, 3 in visuals/day5_output/, 1 MP4, 5 in threads/dayN/)
- **Days documented:** 5 (day1-5 structure)
- **Commands:** 6 (context, sessions, push, list, fetch, gold)
- **Typefully state files:** 1 (day5/thread.typefully_state.json)

All files and absolute paths are listed above for your reference.

# Thread Context â€” Quantum Wallet Build-in-Public

## System

Portable build-in-public toolkit at `scripts/thread/`.

**CLI:** `python3 scripts/thread/thread.py <command>`
- `context --since DATE` â€” gather git + sessions + gold moments
- `sessions --since DATE` / `sessions --id UUID` â€” browse Claude sessions
- `push threads/dayN/thread.md` â€” push to Typefully
- `list` â€” list Typefully drafts
- `gold "moment" --day N` â€” capture a gold moment

**Context sources:**
- `context.md` â€” this file (global: voice, narratives, summaries)
- `gold_moments.md` â€” running log of compelling moments
- `research/` â€” technical writeups, Slack messages, notes
- `threads/dayN/` â€” per-thread drafts and notes
- `images/` â€” screenshots and diagrams
- `visuals/` â€” Python scripts for generating charts
- **Slack MCP** â€” live access to Slack messages (search, threads, channels)

## What This Is

A build-in-public Twitter thread series documenting a post-quantum wallet on Starknet using Falcon-512 signatures. Each update is labeled `[DAY X]` â€” "day" means "episode," not calendar day. Posts can be days or weeks apart. Don't explain gaps.

## Voice

Write like I'm talking to a friend who codes.

- **Casual technical.** Short sentences mixed with longer ones. Sentence fragments only when genuinely emphatic.
- **Grammar imperfections are intentional.** Don't correct them.
- **Confidence without performance.** "I just know it's too much" not "I believe this might be suboptimal."
- **Show work, don't narrate it.** Code blocks and numbers over commentary.
- **Low-key endings.** "Let's see" not "LET'S GOOO." Direction, not hype.
- **Never use:** "Plot twist:", "ðŸ§µ", "Thread:", "Here's the thing...", "Follow for more!", "I'm excited to announce", "Unpopular opinion:". These are death.

## Writing Rules (Strunk)

Apply *The Elements of Style* throughout. The most common mistakes to avoid:

1. **Write actual sentences.** Every sentence needs a subject and a verb. Don't stack fragments disguised as prose. Fragments are permitted only for genuine emphasis (Rule 6).
2. **No comma splices.** Don't join independent clauses with just a comma. Use a semicolon or a conjunction (Rule 5).
3. **Active voice.** "The compiler tracks bounds" not "bounds are tracked by the compiler" (Rule 10).
4. **Positive form.** "The compiler skips overflow checks" not "The compiler doesn't need to add overflow checks" (Rule 11).
5. **Specific and concrete.** "10,000-line file" not "a very large file." "122 bits" not "much smaller" (Rule 12).
6. **Omit needless words.** Every word must tell. Cut filler (Rule 13).
7. **Emphatic words at the end.** "This is where most of the 4x comes from" â€” the payoff lands last (Rule 18).
8. **Tell stories, don't list facts.** "I was about to implement it, then looked at how Miden does their Falcon" â€” show the discovery journey, not a Wikipedia summary.

## Audiences

Write for all three simultaneously:

1. **Cairo/Starknet builders** â€” core audience, full technical depth OK.
2. **Crypto speculators/fans** â€” want stakes and progress, need anchors for unfamiliar metrics.
3. **Ethereum/quantum researchers** â€” know PQ crypto, don't know Cairo, need technical credibility.

When introducing a Cairo-specific concept, add one line of context max. Experts skip it, outsiders get a handle.

## Thread Structure

1. **Hook** â€” create tension. Tease a result, a contrast, or something unexpected.
2. **Work** â€” what I actually did, with code/screenshots/numbers.
3. **Obstacle or insight** â€” pain points are content.
4. **Results** â€” concrete numbers, anchored to something familiar.
5. **Closer** â€” tease what's coming next with specific stakes. Not a summary.

One idea per post. Don't repeat ideas across posts â€” if the hook says it, the body doesn't say it again.

## Format

- Each thread quotes the previous one. Post 1 quotes the previous Day's tweet.
- Hook starts with `[DAY X] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet.`
- The closer should tease something specific with real stakes â€” "If X happens, then Y." End with "Let's see."
- The last two posts (closer + second-to-last) are the most read after the hook. Make them count.

## Running Narratives

### Performance target
Day 1 established ~230k Cairo steps as the target (cost of secp256r1 signature verification on Starknet). Every optimization is measured against this.

### The compiler
Built on Day 3. A Python-to-Cairo compiler that takes arithmetic circuits and generates fully unrolled felt252 code. It tracks worst-case bounds internally, computes shifts, and uses BoundedInt only at final reductions (felt252 hybrid mode). This is the core technical advantage.

### BoundedInt arc
Day 2 introduced BoundedInt as the optimization. Day 3 built the compiler around it. Day 4 corrected Day 2 â€” using BoundedInt for every op overwhelmed the compiler; the hybrid mode is the real win. This correction is an honest, running narrative.

### zknox collaboration
@zknoxhq (@RenaudDUBOIS10, @SimonMasson2) built a Falcon NTT in Cairo independently. Found through @asanso's PQ Ethereum working group. Two teams, complementary work â€” they have Blake2s hash-to-point, we have the faster NTT.

### 230k steps budget breakdown
- NTT: 15,353 steps (7% of budget) â€” solved
- Hash-to-point: Poseidon available now, Blake2s coming April (Starknet 0.14.2)
- Full verification circuit: open question â€” will it fit under 230k?

## Previous Threads Summary

### Day 1
Hook: "Quantum computers will eventually break every wallet on Ethereum."
Content: Cloned s2morrow, benchmarked Falcon-512 at ~800k steps. Too much. Profiled, found secp256r1 costs ~230k â€” that's the target. "I have a theory on how to cut this in half. We'll see if I'm wrong tomorrow."

### Day 2
Hook: "I found a 65% overhead in the Falcon-512 verification. Not math related, it's just the CairoLang VM fighting itself. I've killed this pattern before and I'll do it again."
Content: 65% overhead from store_temp, array ops, downcasts. Cut 20% with BoundedInt. Proposed bounded_int_circuit.py â€” a compiler for arithmetic circuits using BoundedInt. "The fix is to use one fully inlined function. Probably ~4000 lines."

### Day 3
Hook: "Making gangster progress. Turned an elegant NTT algorithm into a brutal 30k-line assembly file. It's nasty but 5x faster."
Content: Built BoundedIntCircuit class. Generated NTT â€” 34,431 steps vs 185,992. Mentioned bytecode-steps tradeoff. "See you soon."

### Day 4
Hook: "Two teams independently wrote the same 10,000-line file. One runs 4x faster. The difference is one design decision."
Content: Compared with zknox â€” shift strategy (every op vs once at end) and reduction width (u256 vs u128). BoundedInt correction (hybrid mode). Hash-to-point: skip rejection sampling via Falcon spec page 31. falcon-rs Rust port passing NIST test vectors. "If the whole thing comes in under 230k steps, we have a deployable post-quantum account contract for @Starknet. Let's see."

## Open Threads for Day 5

- Full Falcon verification circuit â€” does it fit under 230k?
- Hash-to-point implementation with Poseidon
- Account contract integration
- Bytecode-steps tradeoff (mentioned Day 3, never resolved)
- Blake2s integration when 0.14.2 drops

# Thread Toolkit â€” Build-in-Public CLI

Build-in-public Twitter thread toolkit: context gathering, thread drafting, Typefully sync, and visual asset generation for a Falcon-512 post-quantum wallet series on Starknet.

## Quick Reference

```bash
# Gather context for a new thread (git log, sessions, gold moments)
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py context --since 2026-02-11

# Push thread to Typefully (creates or updates draft, uploads images)
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py push scripts/thread/threads/day5/thread.md --dry-run
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py push scripts/thread/threads/day5/thread.md

# List / fetch Typefully drafts
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py list
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py fetch

# Browse Claude Code sessions
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py sessions --since 2026-02-11
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py sessions --id UUID_PREFIX

# Add a gold moment
python3 scripts/thread/thread.py gold "moment description" --day 5

# Generate visuals
python3 scripts/thread/visuals/day5_visuals.py
```

## Environment

Credentials live in `scripts/thread/.env` (git-ignored). Required keys:

```
TYPEFULLY_API_KEY=...
TYPEFULLY_SOCIAL_SET_ID=...
```

## Thread Markdown Format

File: `threads/dayN/thread.md`

```markdown
# Thread Title
reply_to: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/12345

## Post 1
[DAY N] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet. Hook text.

---

## Post 2
Post body. Multiple paragraphs OK.

> ATTACH: image_filename.png

---

## Post 3
More text. End with "Let's see."
```

**Directives:**
- `# Title` â€” draft title in Typefully (first `#` line only)
- `reply_to: URL` â€” quote-tweet target (sets reply-to in Typefully)
- `## Post N` â€” post boundary (N is any number)
- `---` â€” visual separator, ignored by parser
- `> ATTACH: filename.png` â€” image attachment, auto-uploaded to Typefully

**Attachment resolution order:**
1. Relative to the thread's directory (`threads/dayN/`)
2. `visuals/*_output/` directories (e.g. `visuals/day5_output/`)
3. `visuals/thread_output/` (legacy)

**Push behavior:**
- First push creates a draft and saves `thread.typefully_state.json` alongside the markdown
- Subsequent pushes auto-detect the draft ID from the state file and update in place
- Images are uploaded via Typefully's media API (presigned S3), then attached via `media_ids`

## Visuals

Python scripts in `visuals/` generate PNG assets using matplotlib with a shared Tokyo Night palette.

| Script | Output Dir | Images |
|--------|-----------|--------|
| `thread_visuals.py` | `visuals/thread_output/` | `ntt_comparison_code.png`, `ntt_comparison_bars.png`, `ntt_shift_diagram.png` |
| `hash_tradeoff.py` | `visuals/thread_output/` | `hash_tradeoff_cost.png`, `hash_tradeoff_calls.png`, `hash_tradeoff_sensitivity.png` |
| `day5_visuals.py` | `visuals/day5_output/` | `day5_verify_flow.png`, `day5_extraction_chain.png`, `day5_optimization_waterfall.png` |

**New visuals scripts** should follow the pattern:
- Import the Tokyo Night palette constants (copy from existing script)
- Use `_setup_style()`, `_draw_box()`, `_draw_arrow()` helpers
- Output to `visuals/dayN_output/`
- `DPI = 200`, figures 12-16 inches wide

## Directory Layout

```
scripts/thread/
â”œâ”€â”€ thread.py                    # CLI (context, sessions, push, list, fetch, gold)
â”œâ”€â”€ .env                         # Typefully credentials (git-ignored)
â”œâ”€â”€ context.md                   # Voice, narratives, writing rules, audience
â”œâ”€â”€ gold_moments.md              # Running log of breakthroughs
â”œâ”€â”€ published_threads.md         # All published threads (generated by `fetch`)
â”œâ”€â”€ research/                    # Technical writeups (hash design, RÃ©nyi, Slack notes)
â”œâ”€â”€ visuals/                     # Python scripts + generated PNGs
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ thread_visuals.py
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ hash_tradeoff.py
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ day5_visuals.py
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ thread_output/           # Legacy output dir
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ day5_output/             # Day 5 output dir
â””â”€â”€ threads/
    â”œâ”€â”€ day1/ ... day5/          # Per-thread directories
    â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ thread.md            # Draft (push-ready)
    â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ skeleton.md          # Raw notes (optional)
    â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ published.md         # Published version (from `fetch`)
    â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ thread.typefully_state.json  # Draft sync state
    â”‚   â””â”€â”€ media/               # Downloaded media from Typefully
    â””â”€â”€ media/                   # Shared media (legacy)
```

## Writing Guidelines

See `context.md` for full voice and style rules. Key points:

- Hook starts with `[DAY N] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet.`
- Each thread quotes the previous day's tweet via `reply_to:`
- End with "Let's see." â€” direction, not hype
- Show work with code/numbers, don't narrate
- One idea per post, never repeat across posts
- Follow Strunk: active voice, positive form, specific numbers, omit needless words

# Day 4 â€” Published 2026-02-10
url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2021250459210743914

1/11
[DAY 4] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet. Two teams independently wrote the same 10,000-line file. Same algorithm, same language, same brutal unrolled approach. One runs 4x faster. The difference is one subtle design decision.

That 4x puts Falcon verification under the 230k steps target from Day 1.

2/11
I found them through @asanso's post-quantum Ethereum working group with @drakefjustin and @tcoratger. @RenaudDUBOIS10 and @SimonMasson2 from @zknoxhq built a Falcon NTT in Cairo too â€” fully inlined, no arrays, no function calls. I assumed similar performance and had to benchmark it.

3/11
Both implementations unroll the NTT into ~10k lines of raw felt252 arithmetic. The first difference is how they handle negative intermediates from butterfly operations. zknox shifts every subtraction back to positive immediately; I let values go negative through all 9 stages and shift once at the end.
![](media/post3_61b2b2a3.png)

4/11
The second difference is reduction. zknox reduces from u256. The compiler I built on Day 3 tracks bounds through the whole circuit and knows the max value is 122 bits â€” it fits in u128, which is way cheaper to reduce in Cairo. This is where most of the 4x comes from.
![](media/post4_27a038bc.png)

5/11

# Day 3 â€” Published 2026-01-30
url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2017277443510514149

1/9
[DAY 3] of building a Quantum wallet of @Starknet 
Making gangster progress. Turned an elegant NTT algorithm into a brutal 30k-line assembly file.
It's nasty but 5x faster.

     5â†’[DAY 2] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet.

file.content:
# Day 2 â€” Published 2026-01-28
url: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2016632991892853245

1/11
[DAY 2] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet.
I found a 65% overhead in the Falcon-512 verification.
Not math related, it's just the @CairoLang VM fighting itself.
I've killed this pattern before and I'll do it again.

2/11
store_temp, array_snapshot_pop_front, downcast, array_append, totaling 65.24% of the cost. 
Nothing quantum here ðŸ˜†
![](media/post2_26c9dbfb.png)

3/11
I already cut 20% using Bounded Ints, a primitive that lets you skip overflow checks when you can prove bounds at compile time.
Most efficient way to do arithmetic in Cairo. I believe at most 2 people outside Starkware are using it, not even exaggerating.

4/11
Bounded Ints are so hidden inside the Cairo corelib that I had to create a package using the old 2023_10 edition just to re-export private functions.

content.content:
# Quote Tweet Functionality in Typefully API

Based on my review of the Typefully Public API documentation, **there is no mention of quote tweet or quote functionality**.

## Available X (Twitter) Settings

The only settings documented in the X platform settings object are:

- **`reply_to_url`** â€” URL of a post to reply to
- **`community_id`** â€” Community identifier for posting to X Communities
- **`share_with_followers`** â€” Boolean for sharing with followers only

## How to Create Different Post Types

**Reply:** Set `reply_to_url` to the target post's URL

**Regular Tweet:** Leave all settings empty/null

**Quote Interaction:** Not supported via this API

The documentation does not expose quote tweet creation as a distinct capability. If you need to create quote tweets, you would need to use the native X API instead, as Typefully appears designed for standard posting workflows rather than advanced engagement features like quoting.

So the fix is simple: change `reply_to:` to be embedded in the first post's text instead. Or keep the `reply_to:` as a reply (threading under the previous day), AND also include the URL in Post 1's text to make it a quote tweet.

- Including the URL in Post 1's text makes it a *quote tweet* (shows Day 4 embedded)

They're different things. The user wants to QUOTE Day 4, like previous threads. I need to understand what `reply_to_url` actually does in Typefullyâ€”does it create a reply or a quote tweet? On X, a quote tweet shares someone's tweet with your own comment on top, while a reply responds in the thread under someone's tweet. Let me check the Day 4 published tweet to see what we're working with.

Looking at the URLs: Day 2 is at https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2016632991892853245, Day 3 at https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2017277443510514149, and Day 4 at https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2021250459210743914. The Day 4 thread.md shows `reply_to: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2017277443510514149` (Day 3's URL), but on Twitter it appears as a quote tweet. I'm wondering if Typefully's `reply_to_url` actually creates a quote tweet rather than a traditional reply. Actually, checking the Day 4 thread.md file more carefully, it doesn't seem to have a `reply_to:` line at all.

Let me look at the actual content again. The Day 4 thread.md shows a hook that quotes Day 3, but there's no `reply_to:` directive in the file. So either Day 4 was pushed without the quote and it was added manually in Typefully, or the quoting happened through a different mechanism. The simplest explanation is that on X/Twitter, you create a quote tweet by just including the tweet URL in your post textâ€”when X detects a tweet URL at the end, it automatically renders it as a quote tweet with the referenced tweet embedded below. So the fix would be to remove any `reply_to:` line (which creates a reply instead) and add the tweet URL directly to the post text.

content.text: No `quote_url` in the API. On X, including a tweet URL in the post text renders it as a quote tweet. The fix: move the URL from `reply_to:` into Post 1's text.

# Day 5 Thread
reply_to: https://x.com/feltroidPrime/status/2021250459210743914

## Post 1
[DAY 5] of building a Quantum wallet for @Starknet. I built the full Falcon-512 verification in one afternoon â€” types, hash function, signature checking, cross-language tests. Then spent the next afternoon cutting it by 37%.

132k Cairo steps. The 230k target from Day 1 is beaten.

---

## Post 2
The hash function was the interesting design problem. Falcon needs to hash a message into 512 coefficients mod 12289. The spec uses SHAKE256 with rejection sampling: extract 16 bits, reject if biased, retry. That's branching and variable-length loops, expensive in a ZK VM.

Blake2s would be ideal â€” native opcode, 2-3x cheaper than Poseidon â€” but I asked @Starkware and it won't be available to contracts until 0.14.2 in April. Poseidon it is.

---

## Post 3
I looked at how @0xMiden does their Falcon with Poseidon2. They skip rejection entirely and extract more bits per coefficient instead. The trick is in the Falcon spec itself (page 31): if your hash output is much larger than q, the modular bias becomes negligible.

With 16-bit inputs some residues get 25% more pre-images than others. With 128-bit inputs the bias is parts per 10^38. A Renyi divergence argument makes it formal. Minimum safe is ~50 bits; we extract from 128. Overkill.

---

## Post 4
So I built base-Q extraction chains. Each Poseidon output is a felt252 â€” 251 bits. Split into a low u128 and a high 124-bit part, then extract coefficients with repeated DivRem-by-q: divide, take remainder, repeat. 6 from each half. 12 coefficients per felt252.

22 Poseidon permutations for all 512 coefficients. No rejection, no branching, no variable-length loops.

> ATTACH: day5_extraction_chain.png

---

## Post 5
The BoundedInt type chains for this are painful though. Each DivRem step needs exact quotient and remainder types. Two separate chains because u128 and FeltHigh have different upper bounds. 40+ type definitions just for the extraction logic.

But the compiler uses those bounds to skip every overflow check. Without BoundedInt each division needs a u256 intermediate and a try_into cast back down â€” doubling the cost. Same lesson from Day 2: the pain pays for itself.

---

## Post 6
I also moved the INTT off-chain. Standard Falcon: NTT the signature, multiply by public key, INTT back, check norm. Three transforms. Instead, the signer computes mul_hint = INTT(NTT(s1) * pk_ntt) and sends it alongside the signature. The verifier just re-checks the forward direction: NTT(mul_hint) == NTT(s1) * pk_ntt.

Two NTTs, zero INTTs.

> ATTACH: day5_verify_flow.png

---

## Post 7
Then I found a free optimization. I originally wrote a custom absorb function for the Poseidon sponge â€” rate-2 absorption, padding, domain separation, the whole thing. Then I realized Cairo's built-in poseidon_hash_span does the exact same thing. Replaced 20 lines with one function call. 33% gas reduction on hash_to_point.

---

## Post 8
The next day I went on an optimization sprint. 7 commits in one afternoon.

The verification had three separate 512-element loops: multiply and check the hint, subtract to get s0, compute both norms. I fused them into a single pass. Then unrolled with multi_pop_front K=8. 210k to 132k steps.

> ATTACH: day5_optimization_waterfall.png

---

## Post 9
I also built a companion Rust crate (falcon-rs) with a generic hash trait â€” swap SHAKE256 for Poseidon. It passes NIST's 100 known-answer test vectors for standard Falcon. Same keygen and signing; only the hash changes.

Rust generates all the Cairo test data. Cairo deserializes and checks element-by-element. 27 Cairo tests, 61 Rust tests. https://github.com/feltroidprime/falcon-rs

---

## Post 10
132k steps, down from 800k on Day 1. -83.5%.

Next: wiring this into an actual account contract. __validate__ calls verify, public key in storage packed into 29 felt252 slots, signature + hint in calldata. When Blake2s ships in 0.14.2, @zknoxhq's hash-to-point drops in and we move toward spec-compliant Falcon on a live network. Let's see.

132k Cairo steps. The 230k target from Day 1 is beaten.

content.content:
# Typefully API Documentation Analysis

Based on my review of the provided documentation, here's what I found regarding your specific queries:

## Quote-Related Fields

**There are NO fields named `quote`, `quote_source_url`, `quote_url`, or any quoting-related properties anywhere in this API documentation.** The documentation does not mention quote functionality at all.

## Complete Post Object Schema

The post object schema appears in platform configurations with these documented fields:

```
Post Object:
- text (required, string)
- media_ids (array of UUIDs)
```

That's all. The documentation provides no additional post properties beyond text content and media references.

## Platform-Specific Settings

Each platform has a `settings` object:

- **X**: `reply_to_url`, `community_id`, `share_with_followers`
- **LinkedIn**: Empty object `{}`
- **Mastodon**: Empty object `{}`
- **Threads**: Empty object `{}`
- **Bluesky**: Empty object `{}`

## Key Limitation

The API documentation shows no "quote post" or "retweet with comment" functionality. The create draft endpoint accepts only `text` and `media_ids` for post content. There's no mechanism documented for referencing or quoting another user's post.

The documentation you provided appears complete for draft management, media handling, and basic platform posting, but lacks any advanced features like quoting, threading replies, or cross-post references.

python3 -c "
import requests, json, os, sys
sys.path.insert(0, 'scripts/thread')
from thread import read_dotenv

env = read_dotenv()
api_key = env.get('TYPEFULLY_API_KEY') or os.environ.get('TYPEFULLY_API_KEY')
social_set_id = env.get('TYPEFULLY_SOCIAL_SET_ID') or os.environ.get('TYPEFULLY_SOCIAL_SET_ID')

headers = {'Authorization': f'Bearer {api_key}', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}

# Fetch all drafts to find a published one (Day 4)
url = f'https://api.typefully.com/v2/social-sets/{social_set_id}/drafts?limit=50'
r = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
drafts = r.json().get('results', [])

# Find Day 4 (published, should have quote)
for d in drafts:
    title = d.get('draft_title', '')
    if 'day 4' in title.lower() or 'day4' in title.lower() or 'research week' in title.lower():
        draft_id = d['id']
        detail_url = f'https://api.typefully.com/v2/social-sets/{social_set_id}/drafts/{draft_id}'
        r2 = requests.get(detail_url, headers=headers)
        detail = r2.json()
        # Print the X platform posts structure
        x_data = detail.get('platforms', {}).get('x', {})
        posts = x_data.get('posts', [])
        settings = x_data.get('settings', {})
        print(f'Draft: {title} (id={draft_id})')
        print(f'Settings: {json.dumps(settings, indent=2)}')
        print(f'Post 1 keys: {list(posts[0].keys()) if posts else \"no posts\"}')
        print(f'Post 1 full: {json.dumps(posts[0], indent=2) if posts else \"no posts\"}')
        break
" 2>&1

        continue
    body = {
        'platforms': {
            'x': {
                'enabled': True,
                'posts': [{'text': f'Test {name}'}],
                **settings_override,
            }
        }
    }
    r = requests.post(url, headers=headers, json=body)
    if r.ok:
        did = r.json().get('id')
        print(f'SUCCESS with {name}! draft_id={did}')
        # Check what was stored
        r2 = requests.get(f'https://api.typefully.com/v2/social-sets/{social_set_id}/drafts/{did}', headers=headers)
        x = r2.json().get('platforms', {}).get('x', {})
        print(f'  settings: {json.dumps(x.get(\"settings\"), indent=2)}')
        print(f'  post 1: {json.dumps(x.get(\"posts\", [{}])[0], indent=2)}')
        # Delete the test draft
        requests.delete(f'https://api.typefully.com/v2/social-sets/{social_set_id}/drafts/{did}', headers=headers)
    else:
        details = r.json().get('error', {}).get('details', [])
        fields = [d.get('field', '') for d in details if 'extra' in d.get('type', '')]
        print(f'REJECTED {name}: {fields}')
" 2>&1

content.content: Launching skill: benchmarking-cairo

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /home/felt/PycharmProjects/s2morrow/.claude/skills/benchmarking-cairo

# Benchmarking Cairo

## Overview

Profile Cairo function execution to identify hotspots by steps, calls, range checks, and other builtins. Works with both `scarb execute` (standalone programs) and `snforge test` (Starknet Foundry tests).

If tools are missing, see `installation.md` in this skill directory. The CLI script is `profile.py` in this skill directory.

## REQUIRED: Use the CLI

**Always use `python3 profile.py profile` (from this skill directory) for profiling.** Do NOT run snforge/cairo-profiler/pprof manually â€” the CLI handles the full pipeline deterministically (trace generation, profile building, PNG export, naming).

### snforge mode (test functions)

```bash
python3 profile.py profile \
  --mode snforge \
  --package falcon \
  --test test_ntt_zknox_vs_felt252 \
  --name ntt-zknox-reduced \
  --metric steps
```

### scarb mode (standalone executables)

```bash
python3 profile.py profile \
  --mode scarb \
  --package falcon \
  --executable bench_ntt \
  --args-file tests/data/ntt_input_512.json \
  --name ntt-felt252 \
  --metric steps
```

### CLI arguments

| Argument | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| `--mode` | yes | `snforge` or `scarb` |
| `--package` | yes | Scarb package name (e.g. `falcon`) |
| `--name` | yes | Human-friendly profile label (e.g. `ntt-zknox-reduced`) |
| `--test` | snforge | Test filter passed to `snforge test` |
| `--executable` | scarb | Executable name for `scarb execute` |
| `--args-file` | no | Arguments file for `scarb execute` |
| `--metric` | no | `steps` (default), `rc`, `sierra-gas`, `l2-gas` |
| `--output` | no | Output directory (default: `profiles/`) |
| `--nodefraction` | no | Hide PNG nodes below this fraction of total (default: `0.005`). Use `0` to show all nodes. |
| `--edgefraction` | no | Hide PNG edges below this fraction of total (default: `0.001`). Use `0` to show all edges. |

### CLI exit codes â€” act on errors

| Code | Meaning | What to do |
|------|---------|------------|
| 0 | Success | Read the PNG path from output |
| 1 | Argument error | Fix the CLI invocation |
| 2 | snforge/scarb failed | Check compilation errors, test failures |
| 3 | Trace file not found | Test must PASS to produce a trace. Check test name matches exactly. |
| 4 | cairo-profiler failed | Check trace JSON is valid |
| 5 | pprof PNG export failed | Check graphviz is installed (`apt install graphviz`) |
| 6 | Missing tool | Install the missing tool (see `installation.md`) |

### Output

The CLI produces two files in `profiles/`:
```
profiles/YY-MM-DD-HH:MM_<package>_<name>_<metric>_<commit>.pb.gz
profiles/YY-MM-DD-HH:MM_<package>_<name>_<metric>_<commit>.png
```

After running the CLI, **always read the PNG** to verify the profile shows the expected functions.

## Pitfalls

### Stale trace files

`snfoundry_trace/` keeps old traces. If you change code and re-profile, you MUST re-run `snforge test --save-trace-data` (the CLI does this automatically). **Never build a profile from a trace that predates your code change.**

### Missing functions in the PNG

If a function doesn't appear in the PNG, it may be below the `--nodefraction` threshold. Use `--nodefraction 0` to show all nodes. You can also check the text output (printed by the CLI) â€” functions with 0 flat steps but high cumulative steps are wrappers that delegate all work to callees.

### Timestamp mismatch between pb.gz and png

When running steps manually, the pb.gz and png may get different timestamps if they cross a minute boundary. The CLI computes the timestamp once so both files always match.

## Manual profiling (advanced)

For interactive exploration beyond what the CLI provides:

```bash
# Launch web UI for interactive flame graphs
pprof -http=:8080 profiles/<name>.pb.gz

# View specific sample in terminal
cairo-profiler view profiles/<name>.pb.gz --sample steps --limit 20

# List available samples
cairo-profiler view profiles/<name>.pb.gz --list-samples
```

## Metric reference

| `--metric` | tracked-resource | Samples in profile |
|------------|------------------|--------------------|
| `steps` | `cairo-steps` | steps, calls, range check builtin, memory holes, casm size |
| `rc` | `cairo-steps` | (same as steps, PNG shows range check builtin) |
| `sierra-gas` | `sierra-gas` | sierra gas, calls, casm size |
| `l2-gas` | `sierra-gas` | l2 gas (requires `enable-gas = true` + dispatcher pattern) |

## L2 Gas profiling (snforge)

L2 gas requires **all three**:

1. `[cairo] enable-gas = true` in Scarb.toml
2. `--metric l2-gas` (uses sierra-gas tracking)
3. **Dispatcher pattern** â€” profiled code must run inside a deployed contract

```cairo
#[starknet::interface]
trait IBench<TContractState> {
    fn my_function(self: @TContractState) -> felt252;
}

#[starknet::contract]
mod bench { /* ... */ }

// Test using dispatcher
#[test]
fn bench_my_function() {
    let contract = declare("bench").unwrap().contract_class();
    let (addr, _) = contract.deploy(@array![]).unwrap();
    let dispatcher = IBenchDispatcher { contract_address: addr };
    dispatcher.my_function();
}
```

**Known limitation:** Syscall execution costs (secp256r1, keccak, etc.) are not attributed in the l2 gas profile. Use snforge test output for total gas; use profiler for relative hotspot analysis within Cairo code.

profiles[86f1981]="26-02-12-17:33_falcon_verify-e2e_steps_86f1981.pb.gz"

profiles[027e3a9]="26-02-12-18:15_falcon_verify-e2e_steps_027e3a9.pb.gz"
profiles[5b52758]="26-02-12-18:23_falcon_verify-e2e_steps_5b52758.pb.gz"
profiles[f116483]="26-02-12-18:29_falcon_verify-e2e_steps_f116483.pb.gz"
profiles[a1f5ed9]="26-02-12-20:08_falcon_verify-e2e_steps_a1f5ed9.pb.gz"

for commit in 4158622 a00d9f5 86f1981 c0e7510 027e3a9 5b52758 f116483 a1f5ed9; do
  file="$profiles_dir/${profiles[$commit]}"
  desc=$(git -C /home/felt/PycharmProjects/s2morrow log -1 --format='%s' "$commit" 2>/dev/null)
  verify_line=$(cairo-profiler view "$file" --sample steps --limit 60 2>&1 | grep '"falcon::falcon::verify"')
  verify_steps=$(echo "$verify_line" | grep -oP '^\s*\d+ steps.*\|\s*\K\d+(?= steps.*"falcon::falcon::verify")')
  echo "$commit | $verify_steps steps | $desc"
done

echo ""
echo "Commit   | Steps   | Delta    | Description"
echo "---------|---------|----------|-----------"

prev=0
for entry in \
  "4158622|159403|Baseline (before sprint)" \
  "a00d9f5|133245|u16 â†’ Zq (BoundedInt)" \
  "86f1981|117836|Remove u16/u32 intermediates" \
  "c0e7510|98919|Eliminate felt252 alloc in ntt_fast" \
  "027e3a9|91213|BoundedInt norm check" \
  "5b52758|87606|Fuse sub + norm_squared" \
  "f116483|76295|Fuse compute_norm" \
  "a1f5ed9|63177|Fuse all into single 512 pass"; do
  IFS='|' read -r commit steps desc <<< "$entry"
  if [ "$prev" -gt 0 ]; then
    delta=$(echo "scale=1; ($prev - $steps) * 100 / $prev" | bc)
    printf "%-8s | %7s | -%5s%%  | %s\n" "$commit" "$steps" "$delta" "$desc"
  else
    printf "%-8s | %7s |          | %s\n" "$commit" "$steps" "$desc"
  fi
  prev=$steps
done

echo ""
total_delta=$(echo "scale=1; (159403 - 63177) * 100 / 159403" | bc)
echo "Total: 159,403 â†’ 63,177 = -${total_delta}%"

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Image 2: Base-Q extraction chain
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

def generate_extraction_chain():
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 9), dpi=DPI)
    fig.patch.set_facecolor(BG)
    ax.set_facecolor(BG)
    ax.set_xlim(0, 10)
    ax.set_ylim(0, 10)
    ax.axis("off")

    # Title
    fig.text(0.5, 0.96, "Base-Q Extraction: felt252 to Zq Coefficients",
             fontsize=22, fontweight="bold", color=WHITE, ha="center", fontfamily=SANS)

    # --- Top: felt252 ---
    _draw_box(ax, 5.0, 9.0, 3.5, 0.65, "felt252  (251 bits)",
              facecolor=BG_PANEL, edgecolor=ACCENT_CYAN, textcolor=ACCENT_CYAN,
              fontsize=13, bold=True)

    # Split arrow down
    _draw_arrow(ax, 5.0, 8.65, 5.0, 8.15, color=DIM_WHITE, lw=2)
    ax.text(5.6, 8.4, "split", fontsize=10, color=DIM_WHITE, ha="left",
            fontfamily=SANS, style="italic")

    # --- Two branches ---
    # Left: u128
    left_x = 3.0
    _draw_box(ax, left_x, 7.8, 2.5, 0.55, "u128  (128 bits)",
              facecolor=BG_PANEL, edgecolor=ACCENT_CYAN, textcolor=ACCENT_CYAN,
              fontsize=11, bold=True)

    # Right: FeltHigh
    right_x = 7.0
    _draw_box(ax, right_x, 7.8, 2.5, 0.55, "FeltHigh  (124 bits)",
              facecolor=BG_PANEL, edgecolor=ACCENT_ORANGE, textcolor=ACCENT_ORANGE,
              fontsize=11, bold=True)

    # Fork arrows from split point
    _draw_arrow(ax, 4.2, 8.1, left_x + 0.3, 8.1, color=DIM_WHITE, lw=1.5)
    _draw_arrow(ax, 5.8, 8.1, right_x - 0.3, 8.1, color=DIM_WHITE, lw=1.5)

    # --- DivRem chains ---
    divrem_y_start = 7.15
    divrem_step = 0.72

    for branch_x, branch_color, branch_label, bits_left, discard_bits in [
        (left_x, ACCENT_CYAN, "u128", 128, 47),
        (right_x, ACCENT_ORANGE, "FeltHigh", 124, 42),
    ]:
        for i in range(6):
            y = divrem_y_start - i * divrem_step
            remaining = bits_left - (i + 1) * 14  # ~14 bits per q

            # DivRem box
            box_label = f"DivRem-by-q #{i+1}"
            _draw_box(ax, branch_x, y, 2.2, 0.45, box_label,
                      facecolor="#1a2420" if branch_color == ACCENT_CYAN else "#2d2a1a",
                      edgecolor=branch_color, textcolor=branch_color,
                      fontsize=8.5, bold=False)

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Image 3: Optimization waterfall
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

def generate_optimization_waterfall():
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14, 7), dpi=DPI)
    fig.patch.set_facecolor(BG)
    ax.set_facecolor(BG)

    # Data
    labels = [
        "Start",
        "u16 \u2192 Zq\n(BoundedInt)",
        "felt252\nalloc fix",
        "BoundedInt\nnorm check",
        "Fuse\nsub+norm",
        "Fuse\ncompute",
        "Fuse all +\nunroll K=8",
    ]
    values = [210_888, 189_102, 173_693, 154_776, 147_070, 143_463, 132_152]
    deltas = [""] + [
        f"-{(values[i-1] - values[i]) / values[i-1] * 100:.1f}%"
        for i in range(1, len(values))
    ]

    n = len(values)
    x = np.arange(n)

    # Color gradient: red -> orange -> green
    colors = []
    for i in range(n):
        t = i / (n - 1)
        if t < 0.5:
            # Red to orange
            r = int(0xf7 + (0xff - 0xf7) * (t * 2))
            g = int(0x76 + (0x9e - 0x76) * (t * 2))
            b = int(0x8e + (0x64 - 0x8e) * (t * 2))
        else:
            # Orange to green
            t2 = (t - 0.5) * 2
            r = int(0xff + (0x9e - 0xff) * t2)
            g = int(0x9e + (0xce - 0x9e) * t2)
            b = int(0x64 + (0x6a - 0x64) * t2)
        colors.append(f"#{r:02x}{g:02x}{b:02x}")

    bars = ax.bar(x, values, width=0.65, color=colors, edgecolor="none",
                  alpha=0.9, zorder=3)

    # Value labels on top of each bar
    for i, (val, delta) in enumerate(zip(values, deltas)):
        ax.text(i, val + 3000, f"{val:,}",
                ha="center", va="bottom", fontsize=11, fontweight="bold",
                color=WHITE, fontfamily=MONO)
        if delta:
            ax.text(i, val + 9500, delta,
                    ha="center", va="bottom", fontsize=9, fontweight="bold",
                    color=colors[i], fontfamily=SANS)
